componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Casey, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Monster Worldwide Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Bob Jones, Vice President of Investor Relations, our host for today's call. Mr. Jones, you may begin.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us on Monster Worldwide Second Quarter 2010 Conference Call. We will have formal remarks from Sal Iannuzzi, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Yates, Executive Vice President and Chief Financ
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us on Monster Worldwide Second Quarter 2010 Conference Call. We will have formal remarks from Sal Iannuzzi, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Yates, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition, several members of our executive management team are available to answer your questions during the Q&A part of the call. They are Darko Dejanovic, CIO and Head of Product; Ted Gilvar, CMO; James Langrock, Chief Accounting Officer; Michael Miller, General Counsel; Art O'Donnell, Global Customer Service; Lise Poulos, Chief Administrative Officer; and Mark Stoever, Corporate Development and Strategic Alliances.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that except for historical information, the statements made during this conference call constitute forward-looking statements under applicable securities laws. Such forward-looking statements involve certain risks and uncertainties, including statements regarding the company’s strategic direction, prospects and future results. Certain factors, including factors outside of our control, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements, including economic and other conditions in the markets in which we operate, risks associated with acquisitions of dispositions, competition and the other risks discussed in our Form 10-K and our other filings made with the Securities & Exchange Commission.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Sal.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you all for joining us on our second quarter conference call. Before we get in into a discussion of the quarter, I'd like to welcome Kathy Paladino, who has joined us as Head of North American Sales. Kathy was most r
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Good afternoon, and thank you all for joining us on our second quarter conference call. Before we get in into a discussion of the quarter, I'd like to welcome Kathy Paladino, who has joined us as Head of North American Sales. Kathy was most recently President of Motorola's Enterprise Mobility Division, a $2-billion division at Motorola. Prior to Motorola's acquisition of Symbol, Kathy was Head of Worldwide Sales at Symbol, which she led the company to its highest sales volume ever. Kathy previously spent eight years at Cisco Systems, leading its U.S. Cable and Emerging Services Provider business.
Steve Cooker, who previously managed our U.S. sales team, will be leading our Global Government Solutions business. Steve has over 10 years of experience in this sector. The Government sector is a large market opportunity for us, and we are well positioned to expand our presence internationally and domestically with local state and federal agencies. Having both Kathy and Steve as part of our senior management team will substantially increase our firepower in the important North American and Global Government markets.
During the second quarter, we demonstrated solid execution. Our strategy of using Monster's innovative technology and product portfolio to create significant value for our customers and job seekers is making progress. The clearest evidence of our progress is that bookings increased to $208 million, up 19% year-over-year, and we're at the high end of our expectations. This performance was achieved despite the increased global macroeconomic uncertainty and the negative impact of currency translation. 
At the highest level, our value proposition is simple. We provide to our clients the broadest range of the most relevant candidate, and we do this efficiently and in a manner which maximizes the return on investments. Our customers are recognizing that Monster is much more than a job board, as we compete against general and vertical job boards and newer forms of competition. We are able to deliver a portfolio of products and services that provide compelling solutions to each of our clients. 
Our ability to offer these solutions is based on several key competitive strengths. We reach a wider audience of the active and passive seekers than any of our traditional competitors. We do this with our recruitment sites, professional communities and through our Career Ad Network. Our scale will only be enhanced with the completion of the pending acquisition of Yahoo! HotJobs. The combination of our scale and ability to precisely match the appropriate candidate with the right job as a result of our proprietary 6Sense technology is unsurpassed in the industry. Our broad product array, including media products, can be customized and packaged to meet client requirements.
Our unmatched global reach is a competitive strength to servicing international enterprise client. Our technology investments we have made ensure the privacy and security of the data shared by our seekers and our employers. 
Our sales force is now using the full scope of our product and service offering to create an enhanced solution for our client. As a result, our clients are allocating their highest share of their recruitment spend with Monster. Based on our bookings growth, coupled with an analysis of our win-loss trend, we believe we are gaining market share. There were a number of key indicators of that success in the market.
I know that the bookings in the quarter increased by 19% with a 57% increase in Asia, a 20% increase in Europe and 15% increase in North America. We have also seen strong performance in most of our verticals. In North America, our e-Commerce business, which is used by small businesses and is a leading indicator of economic health, had a 32% year-over-year growth. Year-to-date, our retention rate for existing customers and our rate of acquisition of new customers substantially improved over last year in all countries and geography. 
In the first half of the year, we booked business with more than 100,000 accounts in North America and Europe of which more than 30,000 were new accounts. We have also seen more of our customers purchase all cycles to replenish depleted hosting inventories. Power Resume Search or PRS became available to all of our clients in North America and in the United Kingdom in early Q3. During Q2, PRS accounted for 40% of our search license bookings in those countries. Considering it commands a 30% premium price, the result has been impressive and demonstrates the strength of the product offering. Ultimately, we believe PRS will be adopted by the majority of our larger customers. In September, we are moving from beta to launch in France and are on plan for beta testing in Australia.
In the quarter, Career Ad Network or CAN continues to show solid results for our customers in North America. Our penetration in France, Netherlands and Italy is increasing, and there is opportunity for growth both in Germany and the United Kingdom. I would now like to outline our top priorities over the next several quarters.
We will continue to aggressively communicate our enhanced value proposition to the market, and this will enable us to continue to gain share. With respect to the HotJobs acquisition and the regulatory review, we are pleased with the progress and currently expect to close the transaction in the third quarter. Once successfully integrated with Monster, our seeker audience will significantly expand, our client base will be broader and both seekers and employers will benefit from the increased scale and array of products and solutions and precision of our 6Sense technology.
We will continue to focus on developing additional products and services powered by our 6Sense technology. We know that 6Sense technology is superior for analyzing and processing resume and profile data. We are developing solutions that allow our customers to use the technology not only for sourcing and hiring candidates from Monster but to manage an entire candidate flow from all other sources. We are developing solutions that will assist our customers in managing their talent beyond just recruiting. We are encouraged by the feedback we are getting from our customers. In fact, MRINetwork, a large and progressive staffing company, has already purchased our solution, giving us further confidence of its future success.
From a financial perspective, we are focused on improving profitability. We are pleased to report that pro forma EBITDA in Q2 was $28 million compared to just $3 million in Q1. As we look forward, I'd like to comment on the economic environment as we see it today and our 2010 outlook. It is an understatement, that the outlook for the global economies remain highly uncertain, difficult to predict and volatile. While it's true that a number of key economies around the world remain fragile, we subscribe to the current consensus view that we will not have a double-digit recession. With that in mind, we stay vigilant and continue to be disciplined on spending. 
Most of our customers' sentiment has turned positive regarding business investment and expanding the labor force. Our customers, on a global basis, are indicating that they expect to spend more amounts to products and services. We believe this is partially reflective of the recovering economy, but also reflective of Monster's improved performance. Customers have cited our broad product portfolio and excellent customer service as reasons to increase their spend with Monster. 
Monster's most productive way, outsourcing talent. Some of our customers use our products to improve their internal efficiency. Some use our products to source new talent. Some to replace a normal level of churn and for many, it's a combination of all those reasons. For the accounts, which reduced their spend or did not renew, most tell us they don't have the budget or the need. They are not going to a competitor. We continue to believe that the most important near-term indicator of our success is booking. 
Based on our current view of the global economy, we believe the year-over-year increase in bookings in 2010 will be in the upper part of the 15% to 20% range. This is expected to translate into 2010 revenue in the range of $890 million to $925 million. For operating expenses, as most of you know, we have eliminated over $200 million of cost over the last three years, while at the same time rebuilt our sales force, our products, the technology platform and customer service. 
We have essentially rebuilt Monster. We are now focusing resources on getting our product to the market, expanding the Monster brand globally and growing the company on a profitable basis. With that in mind and based on our spend in Q2, we expect total operating expenses in 2010 to be flat to up 2% versus our previous guidance of up 3% to 6%. For 2010, we are now forecasting a loss of $0.14 per share to a loss of $0.06 per share that compares to our previous guidance of a loss of $0.20 per share to a loss of $0.12 per share. 
I'll now turn the call over to Tim for more detailed review of the financial and our outlook. Tim?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sal, and good evening, everyone. As I did last quarter, I will be using slides to guide our conversations through the financials. You can see these slides on the webcast, and they are available for download on our Investor Relations website.
componenttext:
Thank you, Sal, and good evening, everyone. As I did last quarter, I will be using slides to guide our conversations through the financials. You can see these slides on the webcast, and they are available for download on our Investor Relations website. 
Turning now to Slide 1 or Q2 Pro Forma Income Statement. Revenue of $215 million was flat on a sequential basis and down 4% on a year-over-year basis. This result was at the midpoint of our guidance range. Operating expense of $213 million was down 11% sequentially and down 1% on a year-over-year basis. 
On a year-over-year basis, revenue was negatively impacted by $800,000 of currency translation, while operating expenses were favorably impacted by $600,000 or an insignificant net currency impact of $200,000. Interest expense was $1 million. Equity loss, primarily reflecting our investment in CareerOne Australia, was $800,000. Net loss was $200,000 or breakeven. EBITDA on a pro forma basis was $28.4 million, an EBITDA margin of 13%.
Slide 2 is our GAAP to Non-GAAP Reconciliation. The reconciling items were $500,000 expense on the salary and related line, representing severance expense; $5.2 million expense on the office and general line, representing costs associated with the HotJobs transaction, primarily legal fees and costs associated with the FTC review process; and positive $1.9 million interest income, representing partial recoveries on our auction rate securities. These pro forma adjustments totaled negative $2.8 million after tax in the quarter.
Slide 3 is our Q2 2010 Pro Forma Expense Trend slide. Total operating expense during the quarter was $213 million, down 11% from the prior quarter and down 1% from the prior year. Total headcount in the quarter was 5,546, a reduction of 453 from last year at this time. Total salary and related expense was down 6% from the prior quarter, reflecting the normal reduction in employee benefit expense incurred during the first quarter. Marketing expense was down 21% from the prior quarter, reflecting the anticipated reduction in spending associated with the 6Sense product launch, including Super Bowl advertising incurred in Q1. Office and general expense was down 11% sequentially, reflecting our continuing expense disciplines.
Slide 4 is Bookings and Revenue Trend. As Sal noted, bookings increased year-over-year by 19% at the upper end of our range. As anticipated and reflecting a somewhat slower second quarter, bookings were 5% lower on a sequential basis. The strength of our bookings was broadly spread across our geographies in China. Asia, the smallest absolute dollar contributor to our bookings, experienced the strongest year-over-year growth at 57%. Within Asia, Korea remains our strongest contributor on a percentage year-over-year growth basis with bookings up 86%. We also experienced strong year-over-year bookings growth in India, 63% and China, 37%. 
New York region produced the second strongest percentage growth on a year-over-year basis at 20%. All major countries in Europe showed year-over-year bookings growth. During the second quarter, Sweden remained our largest percentage gain contributor, up 79%. Importantly, Germany's bookings picked up this quarter and were up 28%, joining France, Italy and Switzerland with growth above 20%. The Netherlands and Belgium experienced year-over-year growth around 10%. United Kingdom had the slowest growth in the region, up 2% year-over-year, and we believe this below-average growth, primarily reflects continuing macroeconomic concerns in that market.
North America was the slowest growing of our major regions this quarter, but still had a healthy 16% year-over-year increase. Sal noted that we continue to experience strong year-over-year growth in our e-Comm channel, up 32%. Overall, we experienced strong performance from our commercial clients whether serviced by our field or telesales organization, with the strongest results from our larger enterprise clients, who utilize the broadest range of our products.
As we have previously noted, the results of our large Government business are lumpier than the rest of our business. After an extremely strong Q1 in terms of year-over-year growth, our Government business was up only 3% year-over-year in the second quarter. Our staffing channel and our healthcare channel both experienced subpar results during the quarter. We expect the HotJobs acquisition to strengthen our position in both the staffing and healthcare verticals.
Slide 5 shows the results of our operating segments. Reiterating a general caveat, since we moved to a global functional organization, we view the results of our Career business more on a global basis than on a geographic basis, and a number of cost allocations are spread based on revenue or activity-based allocations methodologies. That having been said, the revenue of the combined Careers business was up 1% sequentially. And operating income of the combined Careers business was $13.5 million, producing an operating margin of 7.4% and an EBITDA margin of 18%. 
On a sequential basis, the operating margin of both our Careers North America and our Career International segments showed significant improvement; a 19-point improvement in margin for North America and an 8.5-point improvement in the margin of our International segment. We know, of course, that North America's margins improved more than International during the quarter. There were several primary reasons for this difference and two have occurred. First, we spent a greater share of our reduced marketing spend in the European markets during this quarter, and we feel this is being rewarded by strong bookings growth and significant increase in new clients. Second, as we have noted in the past, we are modestly picking up our marketing spend in China. And finally, based on our internal allocation methodologies, a greater percentage of our allocated costs fit the International segment this quarter.
Our IAF business continues to experience mixed performance. This quarter, we had strong performance in our Customer Lead Generation and Display businesses, but the segment is negatively impacted by a reduction in military recruitment spend, which directly impacted our Military.com business. 
Slide 6 is Key Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Items. And most of the significant cash flow items for the quarter were consistent with our expectations. GAAP EBITDA was $22.7 million. Net cash provided by operations was $6.7 million compared to a use of $13.6 million in last year's second quarter. Capital expenditures were $11.9 million. Deferred revenue, at $280 million, was a decrease of $25 million. The major factors contributing to this reduction in deferred were revenue was greater than bookings during the quarter again, so somewhat more was taken out of the deferred revenue account that was put in. Deferred revenue was negatively impacted by currency translation. And most importantly, as we noted last quarter, we expect this deferred revenue will be substantially higher at year end. Our net cash was $251 million, and our total liquidity was $493 million. 
So to summarize the quarter, as Sal noted, the quarter represented continued strong execution of our plans and our most major financial and operational metrics for the quarter was somewhat better than our own expectations coming into the quarter and demonstrates strong progress. Bookings increased 19% year-over-year, while operating expenses were 1% lower on the same basis. This ability to significantly grow the business while controlling expense is a clear indication of the operating leverage potential in the business. Earnings per share were essentially breakeven versus our guidance range of a loss of $0.02 to $0.06. Pro forma EBITDA was $28.4 million, producing an EBITDA margin of 13%. And our total liquidity position remains very strong. 
As we look forward, while we continue to be mindful of the crosscurrents in the markets, we also believe that our ability to execute our plan and provide superior value to our client is becoming increasingly evident. With that as backdrop, we'd like to provide the following guidance for the full year and the third quarter. Please note that this guidance does not include the impact from the proposed acquisition of HotJobs.
Slide 7 summarizes our full year guidance. We are maintaining the full year range for our guidance for bookings of $930 million to $970 million, a 15% to 20% year-over-year increase. Since last quarter, currency has negatively impacted our bookings outlook, but that negative has been made up by increased anticipated customer demand. So we continue to believe that we'll be at the higher end of the bookings range for the year. We are also maintaining our revenue range of $890 million to $925 million, plus or minus 2% on a year-over-year basis. Of course, where we fall within that range is heavily dependent on the timing and mix of bookings as well as the future direction on currency. And we are still going against the headwinds of reduced deferred revenue. 
Q1 2009 deferred revenue was $345 million. Q1 2010 deferred revenue was $305 million, roughly a $10 million per quarter negative impact on revenue. Based on these assumptions and on the actual results for the quarter, we believe EPS will be a loss of $0.14 to $0.06 compared to last quarter's guidance of a loss of $0.20 to $0.12. In order to achieve this EPS result while holding our revenue estimate flat, as Sal noted, we are tightening the outlook for our year-over-year expense growth to flat to plus 2% versus our prior expectation of a 3% to 6% increase.
Slide 8 is our Q3 2010 Guidance. We anticipate bookings to be in the range of $215 million to $225 million, a 16% to 21% year-over-year increase. Revenue will be $218 million to $228 million, a 1% to 6% increase year-over-year, our first quarterly revenue increased since Q3 2008. Gross or earnings per share will be between a loss of $0.02 and a profit of $0.02.  We'd like to update the financial parameters we have been previously provided on the acquisition of the projects. On a full year 2011 basis, we expect the acquisition to contribute between $20 million and $40 million of EBITDA and between $0.06 and $0.12 of earnings per share. That expectation has not changed. We currently anticipate it closing in the third quarter. Of course, the exact timing will have an impact on the results of Q3. 
We do not know at this time how many weeks during the quarter we will benefit from being able to include the HotJobs results in our results. And of course, from a revenue recognition point of view, we get different results depending on exactly when in the quarter we closed. We will, of course, fully disclose the impact of the HotJobs acquisition on our Q3 reporting results. 
For the fourth quarter, as we have previously indicated, we expect that the acquisition would modestly contribute to pro forma EBITDA and EPS. We estimate total acquisition-related costs to be around $30 million, including the $9.6 million which has already been incurred in Q1 and Q2. The major reason for the increase from our prior estimate of $25 million are incremental costs related to our presentations to the SEC. In fact, in his comments, Sal noted a number of the business benefits we believe the HotJobs acquisition will bring. 
In addition to the profitability I have just articulated, it is important to remember that the cost of the increased traffic under the Yahoo! traffic deal is fully covered in our outlook of $20 million to $40 million of EBITDA. And that traffic will benefit all Monster's clients and make us more competitive in the market, but our profitability outlook does not include any of that potential benefit. 
In addition, we believe that current HotJobs clients will benefit from Monster's superior product offering and we'll be able to extend our business with those clients. One simple example of that is our Power Resume Search, where HotJobs does not have a comparable product offering. 
Before turning the call back to Sal, I'd like to announce that Bob Jones, our longtime Head of Investor Relations, has decided to return to the IR Consulting business, and Monster is very pleased to be one of his initial clients. Lori Chaitman, who is with us on the call today, will assume responsibilities as Head of IR for Monster. Most recently, Lori was a senior member of the Motorola IR team and Head of IR at Symbol prior to the acquisition. We are happy to have Lori join us, and we wish Bob the best of luck in his new endeavors. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call back to Sal to wrap up.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Tim. It is clear that we're moving this company in the right direction. Our ability to provide unique solutions to customers is differentiating us from both traditional and new competitors. As we mentioned, bookings are expected to grow
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Tim. It is clear that we're moving this company in the right direction. Our ability to provide unique solutions to customers is differentiating us from both traditional and new competitors. As we mentioned, bookings are expected to grow at the high end of the 15% to 20% range. 
Customer retention and rate of acquisition of new customers are improving. Customers have indicated that they will allocate more of their recruitment budget to Monster's products and solutions. These two points are testament that the investments we have made are creating significant value for our customers. Irrespective of the pace of the economic recovery, we will continue to focus on penetrating our customer base, we'll enhance value proposition and gain market share globally. As we successfully execute our product strategy and maintain our discipline on cost, we will improve the financial performance of the company. 
Before we take questions, I want to thank our customers, employees and shareholders for their ongoing support. We look forward to what's ahead. Thank you very much. Operator, will you please open up to questions.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could give us an update on the pricing environment in North America and international as we had in the second half of the year and then to 2011.
componenttext: Just wondering if you could give us an update on the pricing environment in North America and international as we had in the second half of the year and then to 2011.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, in general, in my opinion, there's certainly competition, but I think what we're seeing is basically stabilization. And there were transactions where I think that because of our product mix, et cetera, we gain greater value. Certainly, that's tru
componenttext: I think, in general, in my opinion, there's certainly competition, but I think what we're seeing is basically stabilization. And there were transactions where I think that because of our product mix, et cetera, we gain greater value. Certainly, that's true in the search area with regard to PRS. But we don't see any marked difference or any increased competition in the pricing arena at this time. Things are, I guess best way to put it is things are fairly consistent with what they have been for the past year or so.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Mark Mahaney from Citi.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Mark Mahaney from Citi.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Sal, this is Neil Doshi calling in for Mark. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the competitive environment, especially as other countries are facing economic difficulties. Has that been an opportunity for you guys? And then also, k
componenttext: Sal, this is Neil Doshi calling in for Mark. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the competitive environment, especially as other countries are facing economic difficulties. Has that been an opportunity for you guys? And then also, kind of at home here in North America, are you seeing more competition from, I guess, social networking sites like LinkedIn or Facebook?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, with regard to the international market, most of the countries, thankfully, that are still having difficulties, for example, Greek, which was heavily in the news in Q2, we don't really have much of a presence, if any. It's just not significa
componenttext: First of all, with regard to the international market, most of the countries, thankfully, that are still having difficulties, for example, Greek, which was heavily in the news in Q2, we don't really have much of a presence, if any. It's just not significant to us at all. I think the encouraging thing is that in spite of the news and as it continue to filter out about what the situation was in Greece and in a few other countries, particularly in Europe, what we actually saw is business kept on increasing in momentum and the sentiment in Europe actually continue to improve. The exception to that is the U.K., in terms of momentum of growth. But even there, we've stabilized and we're up very slightly, certainly not where we'd like to be yet. But the overall mood in Europe is positive. One of the most interesting things that we noticed during the quarter is that we would have expected more negative reaction given the momentum of the news in Europe. But the news in Europe seem to have more of a cooling effect here in the United States than it seems to have Europe itself. Now we think that's obviously a temporary phenomenon. What we're seeing so far in July gives us a hope that both the performance here in the United States and in Europe will continue to improve. In terms of the competitive environment, as I noted before, competition is certainly out there. We have competition in virtually every market that we participate in. Fortunately, we do not have any competitors that are on a global scale such as ourselves. We are very unique in that sense. The breadth of the geographic reach of the company is unique. But in each of the markets we play, there is certainly competition and it is significant. With regard to the professional social network, we simply have not seen any type of significant impact on our business. As I've said before, I think, certainly, that they're being utilized by some of our customers. It's a technique. It's a methodology that certainly has a place within the recruitment process. But in terms of impact in our business, we just haven't seen any significant impact at all.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010

componenttext: Our next question will come from Tim McHugh from William Blair.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I want to ask about the expenses. They came in lower than expected, and you took down your guidance for the year in terms of the expense growth. Can you just give us a little more color on what drove that? And then what you expect in terms of headcou
componenttext: Yes, I want to ask about the expenses. They came in lower than expected, and you took down your guidance for the year in terms of the expense growth. Can you just give us a little more color on what drove that? And then what you expect in terms of headcount and sales investments across the rest of the year?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to take a shot and then I'll turn it over to Tim. I think, for the rest of the year, as I said in my comments, we've taken down the guidance. We thought we would be up 3% to 6% on the year. Right now, we're estimating something more in the vicin
componenttext: I'm going to take a shot and then I'll turn it over to Tim. I think, for the rest of the year, as I said in my comments, we've taken down the guidance. We thought we would be up 3% to 6% on the year. Right now, we're estimating something more in the vicinity of flat to last year to up about 2%. The majority of that increase has really been in the form of compensation. We took certain costs out last year, particularly in terms of incentive compensation, things of that nature, which we've begun to restore on a limited basis. But I think that given what we've seen in the marketplace, the efficiencies we're able now to draw on, should be coming clearer and clearer. Given the investments we've made over the past several years, we're able to manage the  cost side better and better. So we're seeing the benefit, we're seeing the ability to do that. And if we see an opportunity that we think is important for us to pursue and it involves some degree into investment, we'll pursue that. But I think we can more than accomplish that within the new guidance range that we've given which is the 0:2. Tim?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, Tim, none of the reduction in the potential increase comes out of the sales line or the sales force. It comes out of O&G and some other internal things, and perhaps a little bit less pickup in marketing spend than we had previously an
componenttext: Just to add to that, Tim, none of the reduction in the potential increase comes out of the sales line or the sales force. It comes out of O&G and some other internal things, and perhaps a little bit less pickup in marketing spend than we had previously anticipated. But we have not changed anything in terms of the firepower of getting the product to the market at this stage.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually James Mitchell on behalf of Ingrid Chung. You mentioned that governments and military hiring are somewhat lumpy. How big are governments and military hiring as a percentage of firm-wide revenue, including careers and Internet advertising?
componenttext: It's actually James Mitchell on behalf of Ingrid Chung. You mentioned that governments and military hiring are somewhat lumpy. How big are governments and military hiring as a percentage of firm-wide revenue, including careers and Internet advertising?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there are two thoughts we had in there. One is, in our IAF business, our major site is military.com, and that's a pretty good significant percentage of the total IAF revenue. It's revenue model is display and lead generation advertising, a lot of wh
componenttext: Well, there are two thoughts we had in there. One is, in our IAF business, our major site is military.com, and that's a pretty good significant percentage of the total IAF revenue. It's revenue model is display and lead generation advertising, a lot of which is on the part of the uniformed services as they try to fill their own staffing, people for the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines. And one of the by-products of the current weakness in the job market is the fact that the military has been able to fill its quota at a lower level of advertising spend. And we're seeing that to some extent and that impacts our IAF revenue line. Our Government business, which is part of Careers, is on full year basis, will be up significantly. And this is where we provide recruiting services to the government directly through a variety of different vehicles. For example, the private label of the government's own USAJOBS website. That's just one example. That tends to be larger contracts than our normal run-off-the-mill business. And so when one closes at any given quarter, you can change the result relatively significantly on a percentage basis. It's a pretty good-sized piece of our North American Careers business.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to answer that, and it's a term that, for some reason, we had to take to you. That business tends to be much more lumpy. I find those descriptive than the rest of our business. The deals or the transactions are much more significant, as Tim said. And
componenttext: Just to answer that, and it's a term that, for some reason, we had to take to you. That business tends to be much more lumpy. I find those descriptive than the rest of our business. The deals or the transactions are much more significant, as Tim said. And they'll have to predict in an exact timing. They can move from quarter-to-quarter pretty easily. But it is a very important business to us. And it is one of the reasons we made the change that we noted a little while ago with Steve and had a good fortune being able to bring Kathy in, is to take advantage of the opportunity that is there both in government, state and local. And also important, on the global scale, I think we have a lot of opportunity, based on the experience here in the U.S., to take advantage and build a real global Government business. So we think that's a real opportunity to, not only continue to enjoy the performance we've had there but to build on it.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Mark Marcon from R.W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Mark Marcon from R.W. Baird.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about North America. Can you just talk a little bit more about the trends as it relates to bookings? Just basically what you've seen, not sequentially, and also, how the months played out. And if you can talk a little bit about the impact
componenttext: I wanted to ask about North America. Can you just talk a little bit more about the trends as it relates to bookings? Just basically what you've seen, not sequentially, and also, how the months played out. And if you can talk a little bit about the impact of 6Sense on bookings in North America?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we've seen is that the momentum that started in Q1 continued, really, throughout the quarter. I think that, as you see, we're continuing to be encouraged by the fact that our e-Commerce business continue to grow and continue to be the momentu
componenttext: I think what we've seen is that the momentum that started in Q1 continued, really, throughout the quarter. I think that, as you see, we're continuing to be encouraged by the fact that our e-Commerce business continue to grow and continue to be the momentum that had ended Q1 with. We're up to about 32% growth year-on-year in e-Comm. And as we've noted in prior calls, e-Comm was the first business to really suffer and begin to feel the effects of the recession. And we're hopeful that the robustness of that recovery will continue to flow into a midsized company and into our big customer base. Having said that, we seek, across the country, significant growth. Some regions are growing at a faster clip than others. And so the momentum is good. The channel, the pipeline of transaction continues to build and gives us reason to be somewhat more optimistic with regard to Q3 and beyond. So I think that although we're gratified, maybe the best way to express it, in the 16% growth here in the U.S., obviously, we're anxious to see the growth continue to accelerate from that number. We believe that we'll end up at the high end of the range we've given. I'm hopeful that by Q4, barring any large unforeseen event that we can even go above the 20% in Q4, for the quarter Q4. The momentum appears to be there certainly at this time. There is some, I think, customers -- the overall view out there is customers are much more optimistic, certainly, than they were a year ago. That will be an understatement, the psychology, et cetera, is much more positive. So I think that there is still some hesitation because of the uncertainty. Best way for me to express it is you read the Wall Street Journal on a given day and the story is positive versus the next day that it's negative, so there is some hesitation. But I think plans for our company is to grow, we see every study we look at indicates that customers are planning to hire, in some cases, to replenish the resources that they've reduced during the heart of the recession, in many cases, to add talent. Tim?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: April was the month when I think that the European scare was at its maximum, and we were giving our outlook at the end of April for the bookings for the quarter. It's certainly our own comfort with new bookings. And coming out towards the top end of the r
componenttext: April was the month when I think that the European scare was at its maximum, and we were giving our outlook at the end of April for the bookings for the quarter. It's certainly our own comfort with new bookings. And coming out towards the top end of the range reflects, to some extent, a reduction in May and June of those stresses and strains in the market. And our customer is feeling the same thing. So I think nothing really particular about the pattern, one month to the next, that's worthy of note. But certainly, the tone of the business, I think, firmed up throughout the quarter and has continued to do so.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Also, I believe part of your question was the impact of 6Sense. Of our Search business, 6Sense represented approximately 35% to 40% of the entire market. And that's particularly interesting in the sense that we could not sell it to all of our customers fo
componenttext: Also, I believe part of your question was the impact of 6Sense. Of our Search business, 6Sense represented approximately 35% to 40% of the entire market. And that's particularly interesting in the sense that we could not sell it to all of our customers for the entire quarter. We finished making it available to our customers, actually, in the very beginning of Q3. So we're hopeful. We're very happy with its adoption to date. We're hopeful that, that continues to expand, given that it's available to a wider and wider audience. It's also an interesting sell, in terms of it is higher priced, it's a minimum of 30% premium in price to classic search or our traditional search products. And it is, as you might expect, a slightly longer-term sell. It's really an indication -- a sell that's predicated on proving the value of the ROI of the product. So given that factor, given that it wasn't available for most of Q2, there's still a number of our customers where we're very happy with the results at this time. And just as an aside, as I've said, we introduced it in the United Kingdom this quarter, and the results there are very similar to what we have seen here in the United States. And the momentum is starting off slowly at the beginning of Q2 and build as we got to the end of the quarter. And overall, their results were similar to the results here in the United States. Okay? And we're really anxious to now introduce, in the next few quarters, the next generations of products using the 6Sense technology as its core. I think that it will offer some very interesting prospects as we go forward. As I've said in my comments, where we've shown it so far, to our customers, we're getting some very exciting reactions. So we really look forward to that.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from John Blackledge from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question will come from John Blackledge from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I just had a follow-up on OpEx, given kind of flattish to up 2% OpEx in 2010. Just wondering if you can talk about kind of longer-term expectations for operating expense growth?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: John, it's Tim. I'm happy to take that. We've said throughout this period of time that we took a lot of costs out of the business and we've reinvested in infrastructure product moving generational product, and we've kept spending at a level which essentia
componenttext: John, it's Tim. I'm happy to take that. We've said throughout this period of time that we took a lot of costs out of the business and we've reinvested in infrastructure product moving generational product, and we've kept spending at a level which essentially resulted in cash flow breakeven during that period of time. We fully expect, as the business recovers, that we'll achieve a 25%-type operating margin, reflecting the fact that a lot of the spend has already been incurred to run the business and support the business. So really, there's nothing fundamental. I would suggest to you to say we're going from 0 to 2%, 3% to 6%, except that, that's demonstrating that we have that ability and we're proving that out now.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Sal, you talked about client retention levels and acquisition of new customers both improving. Is there any way to sort of frame that or put some quantitative numbers on that, and sort of put that in context, either sequentially or year-over-year? I mean,
componenttext: Sal, you talked about client retention levels and acquisition of new customers both improving. Is there any way to sort of frame that or put some quantitative numbers on that, and sort of put that in context, either sequentially or year-over-year? I mean, where are we in client retention? Are we at sort of a 70%, 75% level?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that what we're seeing, certainly, now is year-over-year increases in retention rate that are considerable. Although, I think that, for a number of reasons, I'd rather not give the numbers, particularly for competitive reason. But the rate of rete
componenttext: I think that what we're seeing, certainly, now is year-over-year increases in retention rate that are considerable. Although, I think that, for a number of reasons, I'd rather not give the numbers, particularly for competitive reason. But the rate of retention is substantial. The rate of acquiring new customers is also very substantial. What we try to do, particularly in Europe, we were successful with this during the heart of the recession, is to increase our new customer base. And there were sales that -- there were many of them, but unfortunately, they were very small, which is reflected in the numbers as you know them a year ago. What is beginning to happen now is that those customers are coming back and buying on a more robust basis than what they initially purchased. So we're enjoying the fact that we have customers that were able to utilize our products, see how we behave, our customer service reaction, et cetera, and now are coming back and making bigger buys. But both the rate of acquisition of new customers as well as the rate of retention is up significantly.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Tiffany, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Monster Worldwide Quarter Three 2010 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn today's conference over to Ms. Lori Chaitman, Vice President of IR. Thank you, ma'am. You may begin your conference.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and thank you for joining us on Monster Worldwide's Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call. We will have formal remarks from Sal Iannuzzi, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Yates, Executive Vice President and Chief Financi
componenttext:
Good evening, and thank you for joining us on Monster Worldwide's Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call. We will have formal remarks from Sal Iannuzzi, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Yates, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition to Sal and Time, several members of our executive management team are available to answer your questions during the Q&A part of the call. They are Darko Dejanovic, CIO and Head of Product; Ted Gilvar, Chief Marketing Officer; James Langrock, Chief Accounting Officer; Michael Miller, General Counsel; Art O'Donnell, Head of Global Services; Kathy Paladino, Head of North American Sales; Lise Poulos, Chief Administrative Officer; and Mark Stoever, Corporate Development and Strategic Alliances.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that except for historical information, the statements made during this call constitute forward-looking statements under applicable securities laws. Such forward-looking statements involve certain risks and uncertainties, including statements regarding the company’s strategic direction, prospects and future results. Certain factors, including factors outside of our control, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements, including economic and other conditions in the markets in which we operate, risks associated with acquisitions of dispositions, competition and the other risks discussed in our Form 10-K and our other filings made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Sal for his comments.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you,, Lori. Good evening, and thank you, all for joining us for our third quarter conference call.During the quarter, we continue to build momentum with strong bookings growth across all geographies and within our major vertical markets. My commen
componenttext:
Thank you,, Lori. Good evening, and thank you, all for joining us for our third quarter conference call.
During the quarter, we continue to build momentum with strong bookings growth across all geographies and within our major vertical markets. My comments will focus on Monster alone unless otherwise noted. Tim will comment on Monster and HotJobs. In the quarter were reported bookings of $229 million, a year-over-year increase of 23%, exceeded the high end of our guidance despite a negative currency impact. In-line revenue of $223 million, in-line earnings per share of $0.01. $300 million in deferred revenue, a sequential increase of $20 million. 
Our ability to achieve this financial result is based on two factors. First, despite the continuing uncertainty of the globally economy, there has been signs of recovery. And second, our customers are recognizing the effectiveness of our enhanced portfolio of recruitment solutions. We believe that our global market reach, combined with our value-added solutions, are unrivaled in the marketplace and are fueling our strong bookings growth. I want to talk first about our global reach, why it is so significant and how it can be enhanced through the Yahoo! Trovix deals and HotJobs acquisition. Next, I'll talk about our enhanced service offering, highlighting power resume search and our Career Ad Network. Then I will discuss the performance benefits when you combine scale with the position of our innovative products. Lastly, I'll wrap with comments on the global economy and to some expected future performance.
Let me say a few words about our global reach. Including incremental fabric resulting from the Yahoo! Trovix deal, more than 47 million people now visit Monster and Monster partner site on a monthly basis. Aiding in our Career Ad Network, we are able to reach approximately 117 million active and passive job seekers on a monthly basis. 
With HotJobs, we now have over 1,000 newspaper alliances with local presence in all 50 states. These alliances are important to our customers as they significantly expand Monster's global reach. Monster own global language sites in 56 countries and have the number one or two market share position in most of the developed markets. 
We have recently launched a Monster site in Brazil and are encouraged by the early results. One of the primary objectives of the HotJobs and Yahoo! transactions was to provide us additional seeker and client scale in the U.S. Though we've only been operating together for a short time, the integration is going well and we are very pleased with the performance and commitment of the HotJobs team. 
Tim will discuss in his comments that the financial results are consistent with our expectations. We are on track to launch the integrated website in the first quarter of 2011. And we are accelerating the integration of our sales team so that all clients fully understand the powerful value proposition, which is a combination of HotJobs and Monster provide. 
The scale and global reach alone are not sufficient. When that scale is combined with the precision of our 6Sense technology and our unique and customizable product solutions, we have a far superior value proposition for our clients. I'd like to update you on two of those solutions. Our resume search or PRS and career ad network or CAN. 
In Q3, PRS accounted for approximately 45% of search license bookings in North America. In the United Kingdom, PRS was available for the first full quarter and accounted for approximately 40% of the search license bookings. 
We recently introduced PRS in France, and while it's been just a few weeks, the significant customer interest and feedback has been positive. Our [indiscernible] in Australia is underway and we are on track for a commercial launch early next year. In 2011, we plan to launch PRS in additional countries around the world. 
As you know, we are maintaining a significant price premium over classic and we are gratified that so many of our clients see its value. Given our results for PRS to date, we believe it will be the predominant search tool used by our customers. None of our competitors offer a comparable product. 
CAN is the industry's largest recruitment focus ad network. It distributes our customer job advertisement to course a broad array of targeted websites in a very effective way of expanding our fine pool of active and passive seekers. Our customers who use CAN generally in conjunction with the traditional posting products, find a substantial almost double increase in their views and applies. And we find we gained incremental revenue and market share compared to simply offering a traditional job posting. 
Among our major competitors, only HotJobs had a comparable product offered and we are now able to offer fine to combined power of both Monster and Yahoo! networks. We are executing on a global strategy by fully developing 10 in 14 of our top global markets. 
As a result of the combination of unsurpassed scale and product solution offerings, we believe we offer our clients a superior return in their investments when buying from Monster. This is beginning to be evident in our results. 
On a global basis, our renewal rates and our rate of acquisition of new customers has substantially improved and more customers are buying more of our product offerings. In North America and Europe over the first nine months, we booked business with 20,000 more clients, a 16% increase over last year. 
On a global basis, bookings were up 23% before HotJobs. Asia was up 36%, positively impacted by 4% of currency translation. North America was up 31%. Europe was up 17% after absorbing 11% negative impact from currency. 
The bookings of our combined career business increased 28% and accounted for 86% of our total bookings. 
Bookings in our IAF business, which accounted for the remaining 14%, were flat compared to last year, but up sequentially in line with prior year's experience. The flat year-over-year trend was due largely to the reduction of spend from the on-services who have cut the recruitment budget. 
We are very encouraged by the client's reception for all the work we have done over the past three years and our primary objective is to fully execute on the delivery of our value proposition for our global client base.
PRS and CAN are helping us to meet the proven needs of our customers better than any of our competitors, but we are, by no means, finished. For example, we are continuing to develop new products based on our 6Sense technology. For example, our 6Sense enterprise suite is a talent management solution that enables our customers to manage their entire resume base, selecting from multiple sources. In addition to the pile with MRINetwork we mentioned on our last quarterly earnings call, we have had over 100 conversations with potential customers who have expressed serious interest in the product capability and we are working with key potential clients to refine the product. We plan to launch this product family in the second quarter of 2011.
I would now like to take a few moments to provide some historical concepts on the macro factors which have influenced our business over the past several years and how we currently see the economy, the job market, and most importantly, Monster's business evolving for the remainder of 2010 and 2011. 
Before 2008, it was generally agreed that companies will likely to say an increasing global skill shortage over the next several decades. Demographic trends such as the [indiscernible] population, increasing job specialization and the impact of technology drove the belief that talents would be an increasing demand and it will be more difficult to match the right candidate to the right job. 
But then came the financial meltdown and the great recession. Companies around the world touched that. They did not replace voluntary attrition, which itself, slowed down because most employees who had jobs wanted to hold on to them. And all budgets including recruiting were flat. Of course, the combination of these factors had a direct and dramatic effect on Monster. Our bookings began to decline on a year-over-year basis in the second quarter of 2008 and bottomed at a 46% year-over-year decline in the first quarter of 2009. 
Starting in the third quarter of 2009 and through the middle of 2010, business began to stabilize. During this difficult time period, we remained committed to our investment in technology and product innovation. A year ago, in October, we highlighted the economic flows currents [ph] and the  unusually high degree of the economic and business uncertainty, which was affecting us and our clients. At that time, we laid out a financial framework for 2010, which was later confirmed for our annual guidance. 
We are pleased that Monster is currently on track to meet or exceed that guidance. Bookings for the fourth quarter are currently expected to increase 20% to 24% bringing year-over-year growth to 20% to 21%. This compares favorably to our bookings guidance range of 15% to 20% for the year. 
Because of the fall off in deferred revenue, we knew the revenue growth will lag bookings growth, and therefore, we guided revenue to plus or minus 2%. Our current year-over-year growth for the fourth quarter is currently expected to be in the range of 13% to 17%, bringing the full year to flat to down 2% compared to 2009. Our initial outlook on operating expense contemplated a 3% to 6% growth year-over-year. We knew that we wanted to make some incremental investments in our franchise and our people while our business was beginning to rebound. They have been able to make most of those investments while holding operating expense essentially flat or up 1% in 2010. 
For EPS, inclusive of a modest contribution from HotJobs, we have now at our expected loss on a per share basis in the range of a loss of $0.05 to $0.09. While we are pleased to have better exceeded our financial parameters during 2010, we fully expect that the profitability pay off from the investments we have been making will begin to be harvested in the quarters ahead. As we look forward, we are continuing to live in a political and macroeconomic environment, which is highly uncertain, and unemployment continues to be suddenly high. But despite those uncertainties, our business on a global basis has continued to firm throughout the year. 
Clients around the world are beginning to realize that they need to increase their staffing levels and that job churn is beginning to pick up. So our clients are working harder to retain and attract talent. At the same time, hope for profitability and liquidity has continued to improve, and companies has the budget dollars to spend if they choose to. 
Our clients are beginning to refocus on the talent gap, and Monster is ideally situated to capitalize on that trend, even in this [indiscernible] economic environment we are experiencing today. In an environment with global economies continuing to show moderate GDP growth and where unemployment rates continue to be slow to improve, we believe Monster will produce strong financial results as a primary indication for 2011, bookings, including HotJobs, are expected to grow in the 20% to 25% range year-over-year, which was on top of the 23% to 24% growth expected in 2010. 
Based on our outlook for bookings in the fourth quarter, we expect to end the year with a substantially higher deferred revenue balance, which gives us a great start for 2011.
With expected bookings growth in the range of 20% to 25%, revenue is expected to increase at a similar rate. We remain committed for longer-term operating margin potential of 25%. During 2011, we conservatively believe that at least 50% of incremental revenue will drop to the operating income line. As a reminder, operating expenses increased sequentially from Q4 into Q1. And while we expect to see that trend in Q1 2011, we currently do not anticipate as much as a sequential increase as we experienced in the first quarter of 2010. We are also currently expect to be modestly profitable in the first quarter of 2011. We will provide guidance for 2011 when we release our fourth quarter earnings. Now I'd like to turn it over to Tim for additional financial detail.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sal and good evening everyone. As we did last quarter, I'll be using slides to guide our conversation. Before turning to the first slide, I would like to point out that this quarter, we are breaking out the impact of HotJobs and we are updating
componenttext:
Thank you, Sal and good evening everyone. As we did last quarter, I'll be using slides to guide our conversation. Before turning to the first slide, I would like to point out that this quarter, we are breaking out the impact of HotJobs and we are updating our guidance for the fourth quarter and full year to clearly demonstrate its impact. 
Year-over-year and sequential percentage changes shown on the slides compare Monster's results excluding HotJobs. Turning to Slide 1 for Q3, pro forma income statement. Revenue was $231 million. Excluding $8 million from HotJobs, revenue was $223 million, up 4% sequentially and year-over-year. This result was at the midpoint of our guidance range. 
Operating expense was $225 million. Excluding $6 million from HotJobs, OpEx was $219 million, up 3% sequentially and 4% year-over-year. Combined revenue was negatively impacted by $4 million of currency translation while operating expenses were favorably impacted by $3 million for a net negative currency impact of $1 million on a year-over-year basis. 
Interest expense was $1.6 million. Equity loss primarily reflecting our investment in CareerOne Australia was $873,000. Net income of $2 million includes $1 million from HotJobs.
Earnings per share of $0.02 includes $0.01 per share from HotJobs. Excluding HotJobs, EPS came in at the higher end of our negative $0.02 to positive $0.02 per share guidance.
Slide 2 is our GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation. The larger reconciling items were $8.6 million expense on the office in general line representing costs associated with the HotJobs transaction, primarily legal and professional service fees. We continue to forecast the total of $30 million in onetime acquisition and integration costs related to HotJobs. To date, we have incurred $18 million of the $30 million and expect to have the great majority of these onetime costs behind us by the end of the fourth quarter, $1.8 million revenue adjustment representing from purchase accounting related to the acquisition. In total, pro forma adjustments were negative $7.7 million after-tax in the quarter.
Slide 3 is Q3 2010 pro forma expense trends slide. The breakdown of expenses was the following. Total salary and related expense was $119 million. Excluding $2 million from HotJobs, salary and related was up 2% in the prior quarter, reflecting an increase in stock based compensation. Marketing expense was $52 million. Excluding $3.3 million from HotJobs, marketing was up 3% sequentially as a result of higher spending in China, Germany and the U.K. and to support a higher level of revenue in IAF. 
Office and general expense was $55 million. Excluding $745,000 from HotJobs, O&G was up 4% from the prior quarter. Total headcount in the quarter was 5,792 including 207 employees from HotJobs. 
Slide 4 is bookings and revenue trend. Combined bookings increased 26%. Excluding HotJobs, Monster's bookings increased 23% compared to last year. The strength of our year-over-year bookings growth was broadly spread across our geographies and channels. Asia, the smaller absolute dollar contributor, experienced the fastest growth at 36% and was positively impacted by 4% in currency. Within Asia, Career remains our strongest contributor on a percentage growth basis with bookings up 44%. We also experienced strong bookings growth in China, 32%; and India, 30%. North America, excluding bookings from HotJobs, produced the second strongest percentage growth at 31%. Overall, we experienced strong performance from our enterprise clients, both in our field and telesales channels. We also saw strong results from staffing, e-commerce and the government channel. 
Europe region increased 17%, negatively impacted by 11% of currency translation with all major current countries experiencing bookings growth. During the third quarter, Sweden remained our largest percentage gain contributor, up 45%. Importantly, Germany's bookings continue to build momentum with an increase of 26%, joining France, Belgium, Switzerland with double-digit growth. While growth in the U.K. and the Netherlands has lagged the other European countries, business in both markets has definitely begun to pick up and we are expecting strong year-over-year growth in both markets in Q4.
Slide 5 shows the results of our operating segments. For the purpose of this discussion, I will focus on the non-GAAP results inclusive of HotJobs. 
As discussed, combined revenue on a year-over-year basis is up 7%. Within that, our combined Careers business was up 8%, with North American Careers up 15% and the International segment up 2%. 
The revenue of the International segment was negatively impacted by 5% of currency adjustment and by the fact that the economic recovery in some key markets lagged the rest of the global recovery. For example, you will recall that bookings in Germany were essentially flat in the first quarter of this year and bookings in the United Kingdom have continued to lag. These lower growth rates in bookings then flow through revenue over the next several quarters. IRS revenue was up 1%, and Sal has commented on the trends impacting that segment. 
Our combined operating margin was 2.4% during the quarter and was comprised of 19% operating margin in North America, a negative 6.4% operating margin in the International segment. The margin of the International segment is negatively impacted by the comparably later ramp up in revenue I noted above and by the fact that the segment absorbs our continuing investment in China and developing markets. As we have previously commented, we believe that both China and the developing markets represent substantial medium-term opportunities for the company. And we also believe that the International segment will produce very attractive operating margin as revenue in our more-developed markets ramps up. 
IAF had an operating margin of 5.5%. We have continued to maintain most of the cost structure to handle a significantly larger level of revenue, and we'd point out that a relatively small amount of incremental revenue has a significant impact on the operating margin of the IAF segment. 
Finally, corporate expenses were $11.6 million, representing 5% of operating margin. Corporate expenses may have some minor variability from quarter-to-quarter, but will reduce as a percentage of revenue as revenue rebounds.
Slide 6 is key balance sheet and cash flow items. And most of the significant cash flow items for the quarter were consistent with our expectation. GAAP EBITDA was $24.6 million, pro forma EBITDA was $35.6 million, a 15% EBITDA margin. Net cash provided by operations was $18.6 million compared to $11.8 million in last year's third quarter. Capital expenditures was $16.2 million. 
Deferred revenue, including HotJobs, was $313 million. Excluding HotJobs, deferred revenue was $299 million, a sequential increase of approximately $20 million from the prior quarter. We expect that deferred revenue will be significantly higher at year-end. Our net cash was $36 million and our total liquidity comprised of gross cash, and credit available was $259 million.
Summarizing the quarter, our strategy is working, our financial results are meeting or surpassing the expectations we have laid out, and this is the first quarter since Q1 of 2008 when bookings, revenue and deferred revenue all had been up on a year-over-year basis. Sal has already provided guidance for Q4 and the year for Monster on a stand-alone basis, and I will build on that guidance by adding the expected impact of HotJobs. 
As Sal noted, we are moving quickly to integrate the HotJobs segment, and going forward, it will be increasingly difficult to provide meaningful stand-alone financials. So while we fully expect to report to you on our success with the HotJobs client base, we do not intend to separately breakout its income statement starting with the fourth quarter.
Slide 7 summarizes our fourth quarter guidance. We currently expect that Monster's bookings will be up between 20% to 24%, and HotJobs will have bookings of between $18 million and $22 million. This results in a combined bookings range of $328 million to $342 million, a 27% to 32% year-over-year growth. Monster revenue will be up 13% to 17%, and HotJobs will be between $18 million and $22 million, resulting in a combined fourth quarter revenue of $258 million to $272 million, a 21% to 28% year-over-year growth. 
Combined fourth quarter earnings per share will be in the range of $0.04 to $0.08.
Slide 8 is the result in full-year guidance. We currently anticipate that bookings
[Audio Gap]
a 23% to 24% increase. Revenue excluding HotJobs will be $893 million to $903 million flat to down 2%. Including HotJobs, revenue will be $919 million to $933 million, a 1% to 3% increase. Including HotJobs, EPS for the year would be minus $0.09 to minus $0.05 range. Now I would like to turn the call back to Sal.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. It is clear that the investments we are making to enhance our scale and improve our products are gaining traction with our customers. We are looking forward to a strong Q4 and to a strong and profitable 2011. We are moving in the right direct
componenttext: Thanks, Tim. It is clear that the investments we are making to enhance our scale and improve our products are gaining traction with our customers. We are looking forward to a strong Q4 and to a strong and profitable 2011. We are moving in the right direction. We will continue to focus on penetrating our customer universe with the best-in-class offering and we will continue to win where it counts the most, in the clients office. Before we take questions, I want to thank our customers, employees and shareholders for their ongoing support, and we firmly intend to reward you for that support. Operator?

componenttext: In the bookings number, also, obviously, very good in the third quarter with pretty strong momentum heading into 4Q and 2011. Just wondered if you can give us some more color on what's driving the bookings strength, and also, the visibility, just in the context of generally soft global macro labor data?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I'll take the shot first, and Tim maybe able to have -- will add to it. I think, first of all, while economies are still on a strong, as any of us would like to see them around the world, they are picking up. The momentum, clearly, in Europe, Unit
componenttext: I think I'll take the shot first, and Tim maybe able to have -- will add to it. I think, first of all, while economies are still on a strong, as any of us would like to see them around the world, they are picking up. The momentum, clearly, in Europe, United States, North America and Asia is significantly more positive than it was a year ago. If you look at even the Monster MEI reports, you'll see that in virtually every industry, whether it be in Europe or in North America, our MEI in India shows a significant growth year-over-year, as I said, virtually across every industry. So while economies are as strong as we like them, they are gaining strength. In addition to that, I think that our investment, what we've been working on for the past several years, are really starting to take hold with our customers. While we still have work to do and by no means of stopping, I think in what we built and what customers are seeing as us providing solutions rather than just transactional support is really taking hold, and I think that's working in our favor. And I think it's taking market share away from our competitors. So I think, really, bottom line is the combination of both of the economy around the world improving, as well as the fact that Monster and its products, its service, the talent of our sales force as the investments we made in our sales forces essentially are all coming together to produce better results. And I think that it gives us confidence that those results will continue throughout 2011. Just a little bit more color on what's happening, most recently what we're seeing. A year ago, it was very hard to find customers who were planning major recruitment drives, most of which you've read in the paper and what we were seeing is the many customers who were talking about layoffs, some of them in the thousands of people. Right now, what we're starting to see is customers, that a dozen or so that I'm thinking -- that I've seen over two, three weeks, all of which are interested and are planning major recruitment campaigns in these scenarios of their business in the coming years in the field of technology in the field of -- just across-the-board in a number of industries. And the recruitment efforts that go into the thousands of people for a company. So we are encouraged by that. That's something that we have not seen in a while, certainly not on that scale, and that's just one observation or one example, if you will, of what appears to be going on out there, But I also mentioned PRS in my comments. 45% or so in the U.S., 40% in the U.K. is how resume research sell in the search area at a premium price. So customers realize the benefit of that, that service or that product brings to the table. So it's really a combination of things.
