headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, and I'll start and I know Tim will definitely add to this. Revenue, I don't believe, is the current measure of the business because it's really a much more of a lagging indicator. I think what's current and what's showing the momentum of the
componenttext: First of all, and I'll start and I know Tim will definitely add to this. Revenue, I don't believe, is the current measure of the business because it's really a much more of a lagging indicator. I think what's current and what's showing the momentum of the business, clearly, is bookings. And based on what we're seeing, the conversations in the customer's office, the movement of customers, customers coming back to Monster that having dealt with us in sometime, the fact that we have 20,000 new customers this year versus last, those customers are not buying for the first time in this industry. They're coming from somewhere else that they bought before. So I think that we are taking market share. And essentially for CareerBuilder, I think we're taking market share from CareerBuilder. I think we're having some impact on the diocese of the world, if you will. I think we're having impact overseas on some of our competitors there, for example, stone [ph] in Germany and Eastern Europe for that matter. So I think it really cuts a very broad swap.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, did you say EBITDA margin? We're talking about operating margin. I couldn't quite hear the question, but in any event...
componenttext: I think, did you say EBITDA margin? We're talking about operating margin. I couldn't quite hear the question, but in any event...

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I thought you were talking about EBITDA margin impact to the mid-20s, eventually. I was curious how long you thought it might take to get back the economy.
componenttext: Yes, I thought you were talking about EBITDA margin impact to the mid-20s, eventually. I was curious how long you thought it might take to get back the economy.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've been talking about operating margin at getting to 25%. And we think that what we've been saying all along is that the company has significant operating leverage because of the investments we've made and because of the business model. What we're sayi
componenttext: We've been talking about operating margin at getting to 25%. And we think that what we've been saying all along is that the company has significant operating leverage because of the investments we've made and because of the business model. What we're saying for 2011 now that bookings and revenue can grow in the range of 20% to 25%, and that at least 50% of that incremental revenue drops to the bottom line, depending on where you come in, in that range on the bookings and exactly how much of it we dropped to the bottom line, you're making a significant step in the direction obviously back in the direction of the significant profitability. If you extrapolated that just mathematically, you're talking about 2.5 to three years. But I'm not forecasting that in terms of exactly precisely because we want to continue to look at the portfolio of businesses we have. But at the minimum, and Sal will add to this, we're going to return at least 50% of that to the bottom line next year.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that -- look, we're all a little bit gun shy given what's happened in the past couple of years and what we've seen. But given where the market, what we're seeing in the marketplace now, given the comments I just finished making with regard to the
componenttext: I think that -- look, we're all a little bit gun shy given what's happened in the past couple of years and what we've seen. But given where the market, what we're seeing in the marketplace now, given the comments I just finished making with regard to the momentum we see around the world, et cetera, we feel we're going to be conservative and we feel that our estimate for increasing revenue next year in the range of 20% to 25% is certainly within the range of what we can do. I think we're going to continue to watch our expenses very closely. It's what we've always done and we will continue to do that. And we will spend some money when we feel we've earned it, but not until that time. And we intend to bring margin and profitability to our shareholders just as quickly as we can without sacrificing the future. And so I think it's hard to forecast right now, from where we sit today, to forecast when we will be at 25% margin. But having said that, we intend to get there and we intend to get there as fast as we can. And I think that's going to happen. Because of the investments we've we made, they are going to pay off now. We have a significant confidence that that's going to happen. And if we prudently watch the expenses, we'll get there. Now I hate to be negative, but if the economy should, in the middle of next year or at some point in time, take another nose dive around the world, then I think the effect on Monster will be a little bit more muted than it was this last time because of the products and the products that we plan on introducing in the coming months. But I think that it will still, obviously, have an impact. But whether it's, as Tim said, 2.5 years or whether it's in the next year and a half, it's very difficult to predict right now. But I think that we are in the right track, and I think you can do the numbers. Even if we return next year a 20% to 25% increase in revenue and only half of that, and that's a conservative number, goes to the bottom line, I think you can do the arithmetic and see there's quite a transition from where we were this year.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to answer your first version, literally, if you were doing EBITDA margin, probably be a year and a half to two years.
componenttext: And to answer your first version, literally, if you were doing EBITDA margin, probably be a year and a half to two years.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Returning back to profitability, the tax rate that I would use is probably around 35%. Interest would be, I would say, in the $1.5 million to $2 million, probably a little more in the first half of the year. And then as we're generating cash flow, we'll p
componenttext: Returning back to profitability, the tax rate that I would use is probably around 35%. Interest would be, I would say, in the $1.5 million to $2 million, probably a little more in the first half of the year. And then as we're generating cash flow, we'll pay down the debt, so that will start reducing. But I would use $1.5 million to $2 million of interest from a modeling standpoint.

componenttext: And then just a question on...

componenttext: $1.5 million per quarter. $1 million to $2 million. I would say, earlier on, it's probably $2 million, then later out, it's probably about $1.5 million.

componenttext: So we're focused on the quality elements of the traffic HotJobs had. And ideally, the agreement with Yahoo! sort of exclusive placing on their homepage. If I were to guess, I'm saying, 40% to 50% increase in traffic.

componenttextpreview: No, we do. And as you know, we announced the deal. This was for all of North America. So we are also operating up in Canada. But we've started a variety of discussions within Europe, and also, in one of our new emerging markets throughout Latin America. S
componenttext: No, we do. And as you know, we announced the deal. This was for all of North America. So we are also operating up in Canada. But we've started a variety of discussions within Europe, and also, in one of our new emerging markets throughout Latin America. So with the agreement with Yahoo!, we established sort of the ground rules and the profits by which we would reach agreement in any of the markets that make sense. And we are actively exploring many of them already.

componenttext: In light of your revenue expectations for '11, any preliminary thoughts on headcount additions year-over-year? And then secondly, on international, I mean, Tim, you mentioned it's a big opportunity if you can turn it around. Any updated color on kind of where the losses are and where the most rapid improvements could come from in '11 and '12?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: There were two reasons why the operating margin is lagging now. One is the fact that the gap between the bookings growth is not flowing through the revenue as it will next year. So we're operating the business on the headcount in there with a much lower l
componenttext: There were two reasons why the operating margin is lagging now. One is the fact that the gap between the bookings growth is not flowing through the revenue as it will next year. So we're operating the business on the headcount in there with a much lower level of revenue than we're currently achieving in bookings. So that will flow through next year with no increase in headcount. The second factor is investments in China and the developing markets, which I categorize as medium-term opportunities. And what the major developing markets we're talking about, the Eastern Europe and Brazil, we are doing quite well in terms of all the metrics we watched. The results of those are improving, we'd consider to be improving into 2011, offset by, perhaps, some additional spend. But the net of all of that will be an improvement in the investment next year. And in terms of when we think they'll break even, Sal, do you want to...

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that some will begin to break even probably the latter half of next year, and others going forward into 2012. The larger ones, the larger investments, China, perhaps, I think will be the latter half of next year. And Brazil, which is another -- no
componenttext: I think that some will begin to break even probably the latter half of next year, and others going forward into 2012. The larger ones, the larger investments, China, perhaps, I think will be the latter half of next year. And Brazil, which is another -- no way near the investment of China, but certainly a very interesting investment, probably in 2012. But overall, I think, the portfolio, what we call developing countries or emerging markets, I think by the middle to the end of next year, roughly we'll start to show results overall, either flat to positive.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of headcount, nothing really that significant. We always add some sales people as we see opportunity and we can correlate that as we see the bookings develop.
componenttext: And in terms of headcount, nothing really that significant. We always add some sales people as we see opportunity and we can correlate that as we see the bookings develop.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct. We had demands, as you might imagine, after making the reductions we've made and watching the pocketbook very, very closely over the past two years. So certainly, demands within the company requests for more people. And in isolated cases,
componenttext: That's correct. We had demands, as you might imagine, after making the reductions we've made and watching the pocketbook very, very closely over the past two years. So certainly, demands within the company requests for more people. And in isolated cases, as we've been doing throughout this year, we have added some staff very selectively and strategically, and that will continue into next year. But we do not believe that it is of the scale, the size that would certainly offset the kind of expectation that we gave you a little while ago.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Glenn Greene with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Glenn Greene with Oppenheimer.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question, I just wanted to talk a bit more about the 20% to 25% bookings growth expectation for 2011. Certainly, encouraging. I guess I'm somewhat surprised that you're giving that kind of expectation this early on, even before your sort
componenttext: I guess the first question, I just wanted to talk a bit more about the 20% to 25% bookings growth expectation for 2011. Certainly, encouraging. I guess I'm somewhat surprised that you're giving that kind of expectation this early on, even before your sort of fourth quarter seasonal recontracting period. Just want to get the sense for sort of the visibility, your conviction in that number, what gives you the confidence to deliver on it and sort of the underlying macro employment assumption that underlies it?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, we gave it after a great deal of discussion. I think you may be surprised how much discussion. But based on what we're seeing -- based on the facts -- by the way, we gave the guidance, or the expectation I should say, at last year a
componenttext: I think, first of all, we gave it after a great deal of discussion. I think you may be surprised how much discussion. But based on what we're seeing -- based on the facts -- by the way, we gave the guidance, or the expectation I should say, at last year after virtually exactly at the same time. So we feel that given this time of the year, we have some visibility into what to expect and we are doing our planning for next year and have some visibility, and we have a business that builds momentum. Our deferred balance by the end of this year will be significantly higher than a year ago. We expect deferred to be up year-over-year by...

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Including HotJobs, it'll be mostly $400 million, or $100 million more in the year.
componenttext: Including HotJobs, it'll be mostly $400 million, or $100 million more in the year.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you couldn't here that, what James just said is, going into this year, our deferred balance was a little under, I think, $300 million. About $305 million. This year we plan on entering 2011 approximately $100 million better than that. So that gives us
componenttext: If you couldn't here that, what James just said is, going into this year, our deferred balance was a little under, I think, $300 million. About $305 million. This year we plan on entering 2011 approximately $100 million better than that. So that gives us quite a bit more momentum going into 2011 than we had going into this year. And the momentum of the business, as I've said before, really is increasing around the world. And you couple that with the products that has been delivered and are now are talking hold with the customers, the products that we've already seen very strong indications of interest, although we haven't introduced them yet to the market, it gives us confidence that numbers in that range are within our grasp. Now I hedged all of those. The fact that if there is some sort of product loose make event in the world, if economies around the world go in reverse again in a significant way, these numbers most likely will not be achievable. But given the economy we have today, given the unemployment rates that we have today, they stabilize at these levels, we firmly believe we'll be able to get to these kind of numbers.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: I know you don't build up your business based on sort of on unemployment rate expectation or anything like that. But basically, what I'm hearing is sort of a stable economy like this maybe the similar type of overall sort of employment growth that we've been seeing is kind of what you're baking in or sort of assuming for '11.

componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you could talk a little bit about the pricing trends that you're seeing in terms of postings and resume database both in terms of the PRS product as well as the old product?
componenttext: If you could talk a little bit about the pricing trends that you're seeing in terms of postings and resume database both in terms of the PRS product as well as the old product?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think on PRS, as we indicated, when we introduced the product, it's a premium priced product, something premium to traditional or plastic search [ph] as we refer to it. And that pricing stability, as I indicated in my comment, is holding. And we're seei
componenttext: I think on PRS, as we indicated, when we introduced the product, it's a premium priced product, something premium to traditional or plastic search [ph] as we refer to it. And that pricing stability, as I indicated in my comment, is holding. And we're seeing more adoption in the sense of customers seeing that -- PRS is a methodology. To some degree, it is a change in how companies do search for some talents and it's a longer-term sale. It is not a sale that in one conversation happens for the most part. And so as customers are becoming more knowledgeable and are seeing more the value of the product and the benefits that it may bring and as they're listening more to what's coming down the pipe in terms of future products, precision search product predicated on the 6Sense technology the momentum and the conversation is moving less to price and more to the benefit of that technology brings to the table. So that's working well for us. And based on what we're seeing now, that's most likely going to continue. With regard to -- if I quote the rest of the question correctly, with regard to posting, and call it, more traditional product, we're not seeing any significant change. Obviously, an individual customer, the price may go up or go down based on volume of what they're purchasing, et cetera. Whereas an overall matter across the board, things are pretty much even, prices are relatively stable. And maybe in a few cases, I think we're starting to see some improvement.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And are you assuming for next year that pricing will stay basically stable or maybe increase a little bit? Or how do you think about that?
componenttext: And are you assuming for next year that pricing will stay basically stable or maybe increase a little bit? Or how do you think about that?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Based on what we're seeing right now, we think things will remain fairly stable. Obviously, we can't speak to -- as we introduce new products, what that pricing may be and how that will fit in. But obviously, it's just a different market, and we'll see ho
componenttext: Based on what we're seeing right now, we think things will remain fairly stable. Obviously, we can't speak to -- as we introduce new products, what that pricing may be and how that will fit in. But obviously, it's just a different market, and we'll see how it goes. But for the current products, current suite of products, for the most part, I would say, I think it will stay relatively stable. We're not building anything into that 20% to 25% increase for price increases or anything of that sort.

componenttext: As Sal mentioned, in Q1, we got to merge the two sides together. So basically, the traffic that's currently going towards the HotJobs side growth over the Monster's side and the secrets [ph] from the trough as you see on the Yahoo!'s homepage will go directly into the Monster site. The same thing for the employers, we are merging those sites together and merging the customer's base together, as well as the seekers together. So starting sometime in Q1, the experience will be a Monster experience, along with some of the other changes we have or currently making.

componenttext: Darko, you type in the HotJobs and then it'll take you to Monster?

componenttext: Correct. So if you go into a trough, there's going to be a Monster there. If you click on where it's currently HotJobs, there's going to be a Monster there. And you type HotJobs, it will redirect you directly to the Monster. [indiscernible] purposes or any main search engine, if you go there, it's going to automatically direct you to Monster.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lise, do you want to sum it a little bit on that in terms of the training and the bringing together -- how you're helping in bringing the two forces together.
componenttext: Lise, do you want to sum it a little bit on that in terms of the training and the bringing together -- how you're helping in bringing the two forces together.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We started out when we first brought the teams together doing some significant training. Every member of the HotJobs teams went through at least one day of training. Although they're still focusing on their products. And as we bring the two teams to
componenttext: Sure. We started out when we first brought the teams together doing some significant training. Every member of the HotJobs teams went through at least one day of training. Although they're still focusing on their products. And as we bring the two teams together, we will put them through close to two solid weeks of training so that they become fully integrated. We're pretty excited about it. We consider this kind of a privilege to have such as a great talent pipeline for our sales force. So we're focused on that. We're focused on on-boarding them with lots of training. And both teams are pretty excited.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just break out the expectations between North America versus international as we look out to the guidance for both Q4 as well as for next year?
componenttext: Can you just break out the expectations between North America versus international as we look out to the guidance for both Q4 as well as for next year?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not at this time. Maybe we'll get closer to that when we talk about -- when we give more specific guidance -- when we give you the earnings, I should say, for Q4. But right now, I don't think we're prepared for that. And to be honest with you, given our m
componenttext: Not at this time. Maybe we'll get closer to that when we talk about -- when we give more specific guidance -- when we give you the earnings, I should say, for Q4. But right now, I don't think we're prepared for that. And to be honest with you, given our mix and the changes in the economies and political issues, et cetera, in different countries around the world that we operate in, we do operate in 56 different countries, a number of them significant. It really would be very difficult to do that. But overall, as I said, the numbers are 20% to 25% of growth across the board.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Janedis with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Janedis with UBS.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know you guys mentioned you're not going to break out HotJobs going forward. But I think in the past, you talked about maybe around 80-or-so-million of revenue and $20 million to $40 million in EBITDA. And I'm wondering if that still holds. And if you c
componenttext: I know you guys mentioned you're not going to break out HotJobs going forward. But I think in the past, you talked about maybe around 80-or-so-million of revenue and $20 million to $40 million in EBITDA. And I'm wondering if that still holds. And if you could maybe help us out in terms of breaking out next year. Is that 20% to 25% inclusive of HotJobs? What if it would be exclusive?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The 20% to 25% is inclusive of HotJobs, and everything we see about the business and about the acquisition gives us no reason to change the numbers we've talked about historically.
componenttext: The 20% to 25% is inclusive of HotJobs, and everything we see about the business and about the acquisition gives us no reason to change the numbers we've talked about historically.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to give you a little color. When you think about the 20% to 25%, we think of it as approximately 20% of it is Monster. On the high side, 5% would be HotJobs. Those numbers will stay. We just can't account for it in terms of showing how much is the co
componenttext: Just to give you a little color. When you think about the 20% to 25%, we think of it as approximately 20% of it is Monster. On the high side, 5% would be HotJobs. Those numbers will stay. We just can't account for it in terms of showing how much is the contribution from one versus the other as time goes on. As the sales forces are converging and salespeople of HotJobs and salespeople of Monster are working together to present a solution, an overall solution to a customer, it gets very difficult to say how much is HotJobs versus how much will be Monster. I can tell you that this is rarely occurring. As one example I have in mind right now, there was a large staffing company transaction where there was business that have been done with the customer, both from HotJobs as well as from the Monster side. Thankfully, the overall transaction when you added the historical HotJobs and historical Monster, the new transaction was a bit higher in total. But exactly what you could attribute to HotJobs and what you could attribute to Monster, really gets very vague. And even if we would give you numbers, it really will be meaningless.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Sure. We definitely see it as a source of traffic for us and as a tool for the seekers. We launched an iPhone app very recently. iPad is next. Android is following that fairly quickly. Clearly, in addition to being a tool for seekers and the employers, we're also looking at the opportunities to monetize from the advertising standpoint, those channels. So we see it as a very important future channel, and we want to figure out how do we best monetize that tool. And we ask that the launch of that this moment have received a large number of people downloading them and we plan to, almost every quarter, launching a new app for one of these platforms.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask two questions here if I could. First on the Internet advertising segment, there's been a lot of commentary out of some of the education companies, which I believe is a decent-sized customer for IAF. Can you talk about how big that is? A
componenttext: Just wanted to ask two questions here if I could. First on the Internet advertising segment, there's been a lot of commentary out of some of the education companies, which I believe is a decent-sized customer for IAF. Can you talk about how big that is? And then, those companies have talked about kind of cutting back on some of the lead spending that they'll be doing. So have you seen that or is that a source of risk as you look forward? And then secondly, Sal, maybe qualitatively, can you talk a little bit about, you gave one example of the conversations you're having with clients as you try to shift them from HotJobs to kind of the combined basis. But what's been kind of the retention of that client base and the ability to bring the pricing up relative to HotJobs old pricing? Just maybe qualitatively how that's meeting your expectations post the deal?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, with regard to the first part of your question, the decline or the concerns regarding the education activity is not phenomenon of Q3. Its been building throughout the year and really accelerated I guess in Q2 and its continued into
componenttext: I think, first of all, with regard to the first part of your question, the decline or the concerns regarding the education activity is not phenomenon of Q3. Its been building throughout the year and really accelerated I guess in Q2 and its continued into Q3. So we've been preparing and looking for, as business changes, as the methodology changes, as the concerns change for us to change with it and be ready to move into different forums, different client base, et cetera, in addition to our traditional ones to broaden ourselves and diversify in the education space. Overall, our education revenue has stayed relatively flat to slightly improved, and I mean very slightly, which given the term well that's been in the industry, particularly on the pool profits side, we feel very good about that. Now I understand that this coming Monday or Tuesday, the government is going to release more guidance on what's involved, what they want in terms of governance on lead generation and quality of candidate in essence. We're obviously very keen to see that and understand it. But we are really prepared and this is something we've been tackling and dealing with for the past six months, I would say, roughly. And I think on a fairly good position. We'll see what that doctor in test say and then we'll continue to maneuver around it. With regard to pricing at HotJobs et cetera, right now the discussion has been centered much more on the solution, the quality of the product mix and a full-blown solution and we haven't seen any -- most importantly, we haven't seen any significant departures of customers et cetera. And what we have seen -- and in terms of pricing, we see the Monster pricing basically continuing before stabilizing and staying stable. And for the most part, the HotJobs pricing either will improve in where we're be able to introduce a high-quality product, a model product, a different product or staying the same. So we don't see -- we're certainly not seeing a deterioration on the Monster's side or the HotJobs side. In tandem, they seem to be moving along sort of evenly, if you will. I caution, and this has always been -- its a risk in the transaction. We thought it's a risk, in all of Tim's numbers et cetera that we allowed for, and I think fairly conservatively when we enter the transaction, that there could be some breakage. But we haven't seen that yet, but it's early. It's only been two months or so now since the closing of the transaction. And so in the next months, next few quarters, we'll ultimately tell the tale. But as of right now, we don't have any serious concerns. We're watching it carefully. It's something we've been on guard for since conceptualizing the transactions, to be honest with you. But it's not something that surprise us or hurt us to this point in time.

Good afternoon. My name is Tiffany, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I’d like to welcome everyone to the Monster Worldwide quarter three 2010 earnings call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers’ remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. (Operator instructions) Please limit your questions to one question per caller.
At this time, I’d like to turn today’s conference over to Ms. Lori Chaitman, Vice President of IR. Thank you, ma’am, you may begin your conference.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening and thank you for joining us on Monster Worldwide’s third quarter 2010 conference call.We will have formal remarks from Sal Iannuzzi, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Yates, Executive Vice President and Chief Finan
componenttext:
Good evening and thank you for joining us on Monster Worldwide’s third quarter 2010 conference call.
We will have formal remarks from Sal Iannuzzi, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Yates, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition to Sal and Tim, several members of our executive management team are available to answer your questions during the Q&A part of the call. They are Darko Dejanovic, CIO and Head of Product; Ted Gilvar, Chief Marketing Officer; James Langrock, Chief Accounting Officer; Michael Miller, General Counsel; Art O’Donnell, Head of Global Service; Kathy Paladino, Head of North American Sales; Lise Poulos, Chief Administrative Officer; and Mark Stoever, Corporate Development and Strategic Alliances.
Before we begin, I’d like to remind you that except for historical information, the statements made during this call constitute forward-looking statements under applicable securities laws. Such forward-looking statements involve certain risks and uncertainties including statements regarding the company’s strategic direction, prospects and future results.
Certain factors, including factors outside of our control, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements, including economic and other conditions in the markets in which we operate, risks associated with acquisitions or dispositions, competition and the other risks discussed in our Form 10-K and our other filings made with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
With that, I’d like to turn the call over to Sal for his comments.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lori. Good evening and thank you all for joining us for our third quarter conference call. During the quarter we continued to build momentum with strong bookings growth across all geographies and within our major vertical markets.My comments
componenttext:
Thank you, Lori. Good evening and thank you all for joining us for our third quarter conference call. During the quarter we continued to build momentum with strong bookings growth across all geographies and within our major vertical markets.
My comments will focus on Monster alone, unless otherwise noted. Tim will comment on Monster and Hotjobs in the quarter we reported. Bookings of $229 million a year-over-year increase of 23% exceeded the high end of our guidance, despite the negative currency impact, in line revenue of $223 million, in line earnings per share of $0.01; $300 million in deferred revenue, a sequential increase of $20 million.
Our ability to achieve these financial results is based on two factors. First, despite the continuing uncertainty of the global economy, there have been signs of recovery.
Second, our customers are recognizing the effectiveness of our enhanced portfolio of recruitment solutions. We believe that our global market reach combined with our value-added solutions are unrivaled in the marketplace and are fueling a strong bookings growth.
I want to talk first about our global reach, why it is so significant, and how we can be enhanced through the Yahoo! traffic deal and Hotjobs acquisition.
Next, I’ll talk about our enhanced service offering highlighting, Power Resume Search, and our Career Ad Network. And then I will discuss the performance benefits when you combine scale with the precision of our innovative products. Lastly, I will wrap-up with comments on the global economy and build us on our expected future performance.
Let me say a few words about our global reach. Including incremental traffic resulting from the Yahoo! traffic deal, more than 47 million people now visit Monster and Monster-partnered sites on a monthly basis.
In our Career Ad Network, we are able to reach approximately 117 million active and passive job seekers on a monthly basis. With HotJobs, we now have over 1,000 newspaper alliances with local presence in all 50 states.
These alliances are important to our customers as they significantly expand Monster’s local reach. Monster-owns local language sites in 56 countries and has the number one or two market share position in most of the developed markets. We have recently launched a Monster site in Brazil and are encouraged by the early results.
One of the primary objectives of the HotJob and Yahoo! transaction was to provide us additional seeker and client scale in the U.S. While we have only been operating together for a short time, the integration is going well and we are very pleased with the performance and commitments of the HotJobs team.
Tim will discuss in his comments that the financial results are consistent with our expectation. We are on track to launch the integrated Web site in the first quarter of 2011 and we are accelerating integration of our sales team, so they’ll all try and fully understand the powerful value proposition which the combination of HotJobs and Monster provide.
But scale and global reach alone are not sufficient. When that scale is combined with the precision of our 6Sense technology and our unique and customizable product solutions, we have a far superior value proposition for our clients.
I’d like to update you on two of those solutions, Power Resume Search or PRS, and Career Ad Network or CAN. In Q3, PRS accounted for approximately 45% of search license booking in North America. In the United Kingdom, PRS was available for the first full quarter and accounted for approximately 40% of the search license booking.
We recently introduced PRS in France, and while it’s been just a few weeks, there’s significant customer interest, and feedback has been positive. Our beta test in Australia is underway and we’re on track for a commercial launch early next year.
In 2011, we plan to launch PRS in additional countries around the world. As you know, we are maintaining a significant price premium over classic and we’re gratified that so many of our clients see its value. Given our results for PRS to-date, we believe it will be the predominant search tool used by our customers. None of our competitors offers a comparable product.
CAN is the industry’s largest recruitment focused ad network. It distributes our customer job advertisement across a broad array of targeted Web sites and is a very effective way of expanding our clients’ pool of active and passive seekers.
Our customers use CAN generally in conjunction with the traditional posting product find a substantial almost double increase in the views and apply. We gained incremental revenue and market share compared to simply offering a traditional job posting.
Among our major competitors, only HotJobs had a comparable product offering, and we are now able to offer clients a combined power of both Monster and Yahoo! networks. We’re executing on a global strategy by fully developing CAN in 14 of our top global markets.
As a result of the combination of unsurpassed scale and product solution offerings, we believe we offer our clients a superior return on their investments when buying from Monsters. This is beginning to be evident in our results.
On a global basis, our renewal rate and our rate of acquisition of new customers have substantially improved, and more customers are buying more of our product offerings.
In North America and Europe over the first nine months we booked business with 20,000 more clients, a 16% increase over last year. On a global basis, bookings were up 23% before HotJobs. Asia was up 36%, positively impacted by 4% of currency translation. North America was up 31%. Europe was up 17% after observing 11% negative impact from currency.
The bookings of our combined career business increased 28% and accounted for 86% of our total bookings. Bookings in our IAF business, which accounted for the remaining 14% were flat compared to last year, but up sequentially in line with prior year’s experience. The flat year-over-year trend was due largely due to reduction on spend from the armed services, who have cut the recruitment budgets.
We are very encouraged by the client’s reception for all the work we have done over the past three years, and our primary objective is to fully execute on the delivery of our value proposition for our global client base.
PRS and CAN are helping us meet the recruitment needs of our customers better than any of our competitors aware by no means finish. For example, we are continuing to develop new products based on our six sense technology. For example, our Six Sense enterprise suite is a talent management solution that enabled our customers to manage their entire resume base collected from multiple sources.
In addition to the pilot with MRA network we mentioned on our last quarterly earnings call we have had over a 100 conversations with potential customers who have expressed serious interest in the product capability, and we are working with key potential clients to refine the product. We plan to launch this product family in the second quarter of 2011.
I would now like to take a few moments to provide some historical concept. On the macro factors which have influenced our business over the past several years, and how we currently see the economy, the job market, and most importantly, Monster’s business evolving for the remainder of 2010 and 2011.
Before 2008, I would generally agree that companies were likely to take an increasing global skill shortage over the next several decades. Demographic trends such as the aging population, increasing job specialization and the impact of technology drove the belief that talent would be in increasing demand and it would be more difficult to match the right candidate to the right job, but then came the financial meltdown and the great recession.
Companies around the world trudged back. They did not replace voluntary attrition which itself slowed down because most employees who had jobs wanted to hold on to them, and old budgets, including recruiting were slashed.
Of course the combination of these factors had a direct and dramatic effect on Monster. Our bookings began to decline on a year-over-year basis in the second quarter of 2008 and bottomed at a 46% year-over-year decline in the first quarter of 2009. Starting in the third quarter of 2009 and through the middle of 2010 business began to stabilize.
During this difficult time period, we remained committed to our investment in technology and product innovation. A year ago, in October, we highlighted the economic crosscurrent and the unusually high degree of economic and business uncertainty which was affecting us and our clients. At that time, we laid out a financial framework for 2010, which was later confirmed for our annual guidance.
We are pleased that Monster is currently on track to meet or exceed that guidance. Bookings for the fourth quarter are currently expected to increase 20% to 24%, bringing year-over-year growth to 20% to 21%. This compares favorably for our bookings guidance range of 15% to 20% for the year.
Because of the falloff in deferred revenue, we knew that revenue growth will lag bookings growth, and therefore we guided revenue to plus or minus 2%. Our current year-over-year growth for the fourth quarter is currently expected to be in the range of 13% to 17%, bringing the full year to flat to down 2% compared to 2009.
Our initial outlook on operating expense contemplated a 3% to 6% growth year-over-year. We knew that we wanted to make some incremental investments in our franchise and our people while our business was beginning to rebound. We’ve been able to make most of those investments while holding operating expense essentially flat or up 1% in 2010.
For EPS, inclusive of a modest contribution from HotJobs, we have narrowed our expected loss on a per share basis in the range of a loss of $0.05 to $0.09. While we are pleased to have met or exceeded our financial parameters during 2010, we fully expect that the profitability payoff from the investments we have been making will begin to be harvested in the quarters ahead.
As we look forward, we’re continuing to live in a political and macroeconomic environment which is highly uncertain and unemployment continues to significantly high. But despite those uncertainties, our business on a global basis has continued to firm throughout the year.
Clients around the world are beginning to realize that they need to increase their staffing levels and the job churn is beginning to pick up. So our clients are working harder to retain inside talent.
At the same time, corporate profitability and liquidity has continued to improve, and companies have the budget dollars to spend if they choose to. Our clients are beginning to refocus on the talent guy. Monster is ideally situated to capitalize on that front even in this toughest economic environment we are experiencing today.
In an environment where the global economies continued to show moderate GDP growth, and where unemployment rates continued to be slow to improve we believe Monster will produce strong financial result as a primary indication for 2011 bookings, including HotJobs are expected to grow in the 20% to 25% range year-over-year, which is on top of the 23% to 24% growth expected in 2010.
Based on our outlook for bookings in the fourth quarter, we expect to end the year with a substantially higher deferred revenue balance which gives us a great start for 2011. With respect to bookings growth in the range of 20% to 25%, revenue was expected to increase at a similar rate. We remain committed for longer term operating margin percentile of 25%.
During 2011, we conservatively believe that at least 50% of incremental revenue will drop to the operating income line. As a reminder, operating expenses increased sequentially from Q4 into Q1.
While we expect to see that trend in Q1 2011, we currently do not anticipate as much as the sequential increase has we experienced in the first quarter of 2010. We also currently expect to be modestly profitable in the first quarter of 2011. We will provide guidance for 2011 when we release our fourth quarter earnings.
Now, I’d like to turn it over to Tim for additional financial detail.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sal, and good evening, everyone. As we did last quarter, I will be using slides to guide our conversation. Before turning to the first slide I would like to point out that this quarter, we are breaking out the impact of HotJobs and we are updat
componenttext:
Thank you, Sal, and good evening, everyone. As we did last quarter, I will be using slides to guide our conversation. Before turning to the first slide I would like to point out that this quarter, we are breaking out the impact of HotJobs and we are updating our guidance for the fourth quarter and full year to clearly demonstrate its impact. Year-over-year and sequential percentages changes shown on the slides compare Monster’s results, excluding HotJobs.
Turning to slide one, Q3 pro forma income statement; revenue was $231 million, excluding 8 million from HotJobs revenue was $223 million, up 4% sequentially and year-over-year. This result was at the midpoint of our guidance range.
Operating expense was $225 million, excluding $6 million from HotJobs, OpEx was $219 million, up 3% sequentially and 4% year-over-year. Combined revenue was negatively impacted by $4 million of currency translation, while operating expenses was favorably impacted by $3 million for a net negative currency impact of $1 million on a year-over-year basis.
Interest expense was $1.6 million. Equity loss primarily reflecting our investments in CareerOne of Australia was $873,000. Net income of $2 million includes $1 million from HotJobs.
Earnings per share of $0.02 includes $0.01 per share from HotJobs. Excluding HotJobs, EPS came in at the higher end of our negative $0.02 to positive $0.02 per share of guidance.
Slide #two is our GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation. The larger reconciling items were, $8.6 million expense on the office and general line, representing costs associated with the HotJobs transaction, primarily legal and professional service fees.
We continue to forecast a total of $30 million in one-time acquisition and integration costs related to HotJobs. To-date, we have incurred $18 million of the $30 million and expect to have the great majority of these one-time costs behind us by the end of the fourth quarter.
$1.8 million revenue adjustment representing from purchase accounting related to the acquisition. In total, pro forma adjustments were negative $7.7 million after-tax in the quarter.
Slide three is Q3, 2010 pro forma expense trends line. The breakdown of expenses was the following; total salary and related expense was $119 million. Excluding $2 million from HotJobs, salary and related was up 2% from the prior quarter reflecting an increase in stock-based compensation.
Marketing expense was $52 million. Excluding $3.3 million from HotJobs, marketing was up 3% sequentially as a result of higher spending in China, Germany and the U.K., and to support a higher level of revenue in IAF.
Office and general expense was $55 million. Excluding $745,000 from HotJobs, O&G was up 4% from the prior quarter. Total headcount in the quarter was 5,792 including 207 employees from HotJobs.
Slide #four is bookings and revenue trend. Combined bookings increased 26%, excluding HotJobs, Monster’s bookings increased 23% compared to last year. The strength of our year-over-year bookings growth was broadly spread across our geographies and channels. Asia, the smallest absolute dollar contributor experienced the fastest growth at 36%, and was positively impacted by 4% from currency.
Within Asia, Korea remains our strongest contributor on a percentage growth basis with bookings up 44%. We also experienced strong bookings growth in China, 32%, and India, 30%.
North America, excluding booking from our HotJobs, produced the second strongest percentage growth at 31%. Overall, we experienced strong performance from our enterprise clients, both in our field and telesales channels. We also saw strong results from staffing, e-commerce and the government channel.
Europe region increased 17%, negatively impacted by 11% of currency translation with all major countries experiencing bookings growth. During the third quarter, Sweden remained our largest percentage gain contributor, up 45%.
Importantly, Germany’s bookings continued to build momentum with an increase of 26%, joining France, Belgium, and Switzerland with double-digit growth. While growth in the U.K. and the Netherlands has lagged the other European countries, business in both markets has definitely begun to pick up and we are expecting strong year-over-year growth in both markets in Q4.
Slide five shows the results of our operating segments. So the purpose of this discussion, I will focus on the non-GAAP, our non-GAAP results inclusive of HotJobs. As discussed, combined revenue on a year-over-year basis is up 7%, within that our combined careers business was up 8%, with North American careers up 15%, and the International segment up 2%.
The revenue of the International segment was negatively impacted by 5% of currency adjustment and by the fact that the economic recovery in some key markets lagged the rest of the global recovery.
For example, you’ll recall that bookings in Germany were essentially flat in the first quarter of this year, and bookings in United Kingdom have continued to lag, these lower growth rates in bookings then flow through revenue over the next several quarters. IAF revenue was up 1% and Sal has commented on the trends impacting that segment.
Our combined operating margin was 2.4% during the quarter and was comprised of 19% operating margin in North America, a negative 6.4% operating margin in the International segment. The margin of the International segment is negatively impacted by the comparably later ramp up in revenue, I noted above, and by the fact that the segment observes our continuing investment in China and developing markets.
As we have previously commented, we believe both China and the developing markets represent substantial medium-term opportunities for the company, and we also believe that the International segment will produce very attractive operating margins as revenue in our more developed markets ramps up.
IAF had an operating margin of 5.5%. We have continued to maintain most of the cost structure to handle a significantly larger level of revenue and would point out that a relatively small amount of incremental revenue has a significant impact on the operating margin of the IAF segment.
Finally, corporate expenses were $11.6 million, representing 5% of operating margin. Corporate expenses may have some minor variability from quarter-to-quarter, but will reduce as a percentage of revenue as revenue rebounds.
Slide six is key balance sheet and cash flow items. Most of the significant cash flow items for the quarter were consistent with our expectation. GAAP EBITDA was $24.6 million, pro forma EBITDA was $35.6 million, at 15% EBITDA margin.
Net cash provided by operations was $18.6 million compared to $11.8 million in last year’s third quarter. Capital expenditures were $16.2 million.
Deferred revenue including HotJobs was $313 million. Excluding HotJobs deferred revenue was $299 million, a sequential increase of approximately $20 million from the prior quarter. We expected deferred revenue will be significantly higher at year end.
Our net cash was $36 million and our total liquidity comprised of gross cash and credit available was $259 million.
Summarizing the quarter, our strategy is working. Our financial results are meeting or surpassing the expectations we have laid out, and this is the first quarter since Q1 of 2008 when bookings, revenue and deferred revenue all have been up on a year-over-year basis.
Sal has already provided guidance for Q4 and the year for Monster on a standalone basis, and I would build on that guidance by adding the expected impact of HotJobs.
As Sal noted, we are moving quickly to integrate the HotJobs business, and going forward, it will be increasingly difficult to provide meaningful standalone financials. So, while we fully expect to report to you on our success with the HotJobs client base, we do not intend to separately breakout its income statement starting with the fourth quarter.
Slide seven summarizes our fourth quarter guidance. We currently expect that Monster’s bookings will be up between 20% to 24%, and HotJobs will have bookings of between $18 million and $22 million. This results in a combined booking range of $328 million to $342 million, a 27% to 32% year-over-year growth.
Monster revenue will be up 13% to 17% and HotJobs will be between $18 million and $22 million, resulting in a combined fourth quarter revenue of $258 million to $272 million and 21% to 28% year-over-year growth. Combined fourth quarter earnings per share will be in the range of $0.04 to $0.08.
Slide eight is the resultant full year guidance. We currently anticipate that bookings (inaudible) a 23% to 24% increase.
Revenue, excluding HotJobs, was $893 million to $903 million, flat to down 2%. Including HotJobs, revenue will be $919 million to $933 million, a 1% to 3% increase. Including HotJobs, EPS for the year would be minus $0.09 to minus $0.05 range.
Now, I would like to turn the call back to Sal.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. It is clear that the investments we are making to enhance our scale and improve our products are gaining traction with our customers. We’re looking forward to a strong Q4 and for a strong and profitable 2011. We’re moving in the right dir
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. It is clear that the investments we are making to enhance our scale and improve our products are gaining traction with our customers. We’re looking forward to a strong Q4 and for a strong and profitable 2011. We’re moving in the right direction. We will continue to focus on penetrating our customer universe with the best-in-class offering, and we will continue to win where it counts the most, in the clients’ office.
Before we take questions, I want to thank our customers, employees and shareholders for their ongoing support and we firmly intend to reward you for that support. Operator?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) Your first question comes from the line of John Blackledge with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) Your first question comes from the line of John Blackledge with Credit Suisse.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for taking the question. Nice quarter. In the bookings number also obviously very good in the third quarter with pretty strong momentum heading into 4Q in 2011. Just wondering if you can give us some more color on what’s driving the bookings stre
componenttext: Thanks for taking the question. Nice quarter. In the bookings number also obviously very good in the third quarter with pretty strong momentum heading into 4Q in 2011. Just wondering if you can give us some more color on what’s driving the bookings strengths, and also the visibility just in the context of generally soft global macro labor data?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’ll take this short first and I am sure Tim and maybe others will add to it. I think, first of all, while economies still aren’t as strong as any of us would like to see them around the world, they are picking up. The momentum clearly in Europe, Unit
componenttext:
I’ll take this short first and I am sure Tim and maybe others will add to it. I think, first of all, while economies still aren’t as strong as any of us would like to see them around the world, they are picking up. The momentum clearly in Europe, United States, North America and Asia is significantly more positive than it was a year ago. If you look at even the Monster MEI reports you’ll see that in virtually every industry, whether it’d be in Europe or in North America, and for that matter our MEI in India shows a significant growth year-over-year, as I said, virtually, of course, every industry. So, while economies aren’t as strong as we’d like them, they are gaining strength.
In addition to that, I think that our investments what we’ve been working on for the past several years are really starting to take hold with our customers. While we still have work to do, and by no means or stopping, I think from what we’ve built and what customers are seeing has us providing solutions rather than just transactional support is really taking hold and I think that’s working in our favor, and I think it’s taking market share away from our competitors.
So, I think really the bottom line is the combination of both, as the economy around the world improving as well as the fact that Monster and its products, its service, the talent of our sales forces, the investment we’ve made in our sales forces, et cetera all coming together to produce the results. I think that it gives us confidence that those results will continue throughout 2011. Just a little bit more color on most recently what we’re seeing. A year ago, it was very hard to find customers who were planning major recruitment drives; most of which we read in the paper and what we were seeing is many customers who were talking about laid off some of them in the thousands of people.
Right now, what we’re trying to see is there’s about half a dozen or so that I think over the past two, three weeks all of which are interested and are planning major recruitment campaigns in different areas of their business, in the coming year both in the field of technology, just across the board in the number of industries. The recruitment efforts, they are going to the thousands of people per company.
So, we are encouraged by that. That’s something that we have not seen in a while, certainly not on that scale and that’s just none observation or one example if you will of what’s appears to be going on out there. But I also mentioned PRS in my comments; 45% or so in the U.S., 40% in the U.K. is Power Resume Search sales in the search area at a premium price so the customers realize the benefit that that service or that product brings to the table. So, it’s really a combination of things. Tim, anything?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Talk about getting perhaps back to a mid-20s EBITDA margin long-term. I was just wondering, if the economy continued to plug along here, roughly at the same rate, how many years do you think it would take to get to that?Another question I had if could i
componenttext:
Talk about getting perhaps back to a mid-20s EBITDA margin long-term. I was just wondering, if the economy continued to plug along here, roughly at the same rate, how many years do you think it would take to get to that?
Another question I had if could is, when I look at Career Builders’ numbers down like a net post I think they had an up 9% to 10% revenue increase this latest quarter here, and I compare it to your number, up 4% to 7% with or without HotJobs. I am just wondering, when you talk about market share gains, what data are you comparing there, please?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, I’ll start and I know Tim will definitely add to this. Revenue I don’t believe is a current measure of the business, because it’s really much more of a lagging indicator. I think what’s current and what’s showing the momentum of th
componenttext:
First of all, I’ll start and I know Tim will definitely add to this. Revenue I don’t believe is a current measure of the business, because it’s really much more of a lagging indicator. I think what’s current and what’s showing the momentum of the business clearly is booking, and based on what we are seeing, the conversations in the customers office, the movement of customers; customers coming back to Monster that haven’t dealt with us in some time, the fact that we have 20,000 new customers this year versus last. Those customers are not buying for the first time in this industry. They’re coming from somewhere else that they were before.
So, I think that we are taking market share and it’s not just a Career Builders exercise. I think we’re taking market share from Career Builders. I think we are having some impact on the Dices of the world if you will. I think we’re having impacts overseas on some of our competitors there for example, StepStone in Germany and Eastern Europe for that matter. So, I think it’s really across a very broad swap. Tim?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re talking about operating margin. I couldn’t quite hear the question, but in any event -?
componenttext: We’re talking about operating margin. I couldn’t quite hear the question, but in any event -?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I thought you were talking like EBITDA margin getting back to the mid-20s, eventually. I was just curious how long you thought it might take get there if the economy kind of plugged along here?
componenttext: I thought you were talking like EBITDA margin getting back to the mid-20s, eventually. I was just curious how long you thought it might take get there if the economy kind of plugged along here?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We had been talking about operating margin getting to 25%, and we think that what we’ve been saying all along is that the company has significant operating leverage because of the investments we’ve made and because of the business model, and we’re s
componenttext:
We had been talking about operating margin getting to 25%, and we think that what we’ve been saying all along is that the company has significant operating leverage because of the investments we’ve made and because of the business model, and we’re saying for 2011, now that bookings and revenue can grow in the range of 20% to 25%, and that at least 50% of that incremental revenue drops to the bottom line, depending on where you come in, in that range on the bookings and exactly how much of it we got to the bottom line.
You’re making a significant step in the direction, obviously back in the direction of significant profitability. If you extrapolated that just mathematically, you’re talking about two and a half to three years. But I’m not forecasting that in terms of exactly precisely, because we want to continue to look at the portfolio of businesses we have. But at the minimum, Sal will add to this. We’re going to return at least 50% of that to the bottom line next year.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we’re all a little bit gun-shy given what’s happened in the past couple of years, and what we’ve seen. But what we’re seeing in the marketplace, now given the comment, I’ve just finished making with regard to the momentum we see around the
componenttext:
Well, we’re all a little bit gun-shy given what’s happened in the past couple of years, and what we’ve seen. But what we’re seeing in the marketplace, now given the comment, I’ve just finished making with regard to the momentum we see around the world etc., We are given to be conservative, and we feel that our estimate for increasing revenue next year in the range of 20% to 25% is certainly within the range of what we can do.
I think we’re going to continue to watch our expenses very closely as we’ve always done and we will continue to do that. We will spend some money when we feel we’ve earned it, but not until that time. We intend to bring margin and profitability to our shareholders just as quickly as we can without sacrificing the future. So, I think that it’s hard to forecast right now from where we sit today, to forecast when we will be at 25% margin.
Having said that, we intend to get there, and we intend to get there as presently as we can. And I think that’s going to happen because of the investments we’ve made, they are going to pay off now, we have a significant confidence, but that’s going to happen. If we prudently watch the expenses, we’ll get there. Now, I hate to be netting them, but if the economy should in the middle of next year or at some point in time take another notes out around the world, then I think that the effect on amounts that will be a little bit more muted than it was this last time because of the product and the products that we plan on introducing in the coming months. But I think that it will still, obviously have an impact.
As Tim said, in 2.5 years or whether it’s in the next year and a half it’s very difficult to predict right now, but I think that we are on the right track and I think you can do the numbers. Even if we return next year a 20% to 25% increase in revenue and only half of that and that’s a conservative number goes to the bottom line. I think you can do the arithmetic and see those quite a transition from where we were this year.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to answer your first question literally, if you were doing EBITDA margin, probably be a year and half to two years.
componenttext: And to answer your first question literally, if you were doing EBITDA margin, probably be a year and half to two years.

componenttext: Thank you. Just wanted to get in trying to translate the operating margin and income in your preliminary outlook for ‘11 down the P&L a little bit more. Could you give us some color for what kind of interest expense and tax rate in broad parameters you may foresee in 2011?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Returning back to profitability, the tax rate that I would use is probably around 35%. Interest would be I would say in the $1.5 million to $2 million, probably a little more in the first half of the year and then as we’re generating cash flow we’ll p
componenttext: Returning back to profitability, the tax rate that I would use is probably around 35%. Interest would be I would say in the $1.5 million to $2 million, probably a little more in the first half of the year and then as we’re generating cash flow we’ll pay down the debt so that will start reducing, but I would use $1.5 million to $2 million of interest from a modeling standpoint. Those will be $1.5 million per quarter, $1 million to $2 million. I would say earlier on it’s probably $2 million. And then later out it’s probably about $1.5 million.

componenttext: We were focused on sort of the quality elements of the traffic HotJobs had and ideally the agreement with Yahoo!, sort of exclusive placement on their homepage, virtually assures that we are getting the highest quality traffics from all sources of Yahoo! componenttext: We do and as you know, when we announced the deal, this was for all of North America, so we are also operating up in Canada, but we’ve started a variety of discussions within Europe and also in one of our new emerging markets throughout Latin America. So, with the agreement with Yahoo!, we established sort of the ground rules and the process by which we would reach agreement in any of the markets that makes sense and we are actively exploring many at the moment.

Any updated color on kind of where the losses are and where the most rapid improvement could come from in ‘11 and ‘12?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: There were two reasons why the operating margin is lagging. Now, one is the fact that the gap between the bookings growth is not flowing through to revenue as it will next year. So you are operating the business on the headcount in there with a much lower
componenttext:
There were two reasons why the operating margin is lagging. Now, one is the fact that the gap between the bookings growth is not flowing through to revenue as it will next year. So you are operating the business on the headcount in there with a much lower level of revenue than we’re currently achieving in booking. So that will flow through next year with no increase in headcount.
The second factor is investments in China and in developing markets, which I categorized as medium term opportunities. What the major developing markets we’re talking about is Eastern Europe and Brazil. We are doing quite well in terms of all the metrics we’ve watched. The results of those are improving. We consider to be improving into 2011 offset by perhaps some additional spend but the net of all of that will be an improvement in the investment next year. In terms of then we think they are breakeven. Sal, do you want to?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that some will begin to breakeven in probably the latter half of next year and others going forward into 2012. The larger investments in China perhaps I think that would be in the latter half of next year and Brazil which is another nowhere near t
componenttext: I think that some will begin to breakeven in probably the latter half of next year and others going forward into 2012. The larger investments in China perhaps I think that would be in the latter half of next year and Brazil which is another nowhere near the investment of China, but certainly a very investment probably in 2012. But overall I think the portfolio what we call developing countries or emerging markets I think by the middle to the end of next year roughly will start to show itself overall as either flat to positive.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of headcount, nothing really that significant. We always add some salespeople as we see opportunity and we can correlate that as we see the bookings develop.
componenttext: In terms of headcount, nothing really that significant. We always add some salespeople as we see opportunity and we can correlate that as we see the bookings develop.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: That’s correct. We have demands as you might imagine after making the reductions we’ve made and watching the pocketbook very, very closely over the past two years. There were certainly demands within the company it requests for more people. A nice way to locate this, as we’ve been doing throughout this year, we have added some staffs very selectively and strategically and that will continue into next year, but we do not believe that it is of the scale or size that would certainly offset to kind of expectation that we gave you a little while ago.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nice results. I guess the first question. I just wanted to talk a little bit more about the 20% to 25% bookings growth expectation for 2011, it’s certainly encouraging. I guess, I’m somewhat surprised that you’re giving that kind of expectation this
componenttext: Nice results. I guess the first question. I just wanted to talk a little bit more about the 20% to 25% bookings growth expectation for 2011, it’s certainly encouraging. I guess, I’m somewhat surprised that you’re giving that kind of expectation this early on even before your sort of fourth quarter seasonal re-contracting period. I just want to get the sense for visibility, your conviction in that number, what gives you the confidence to deliver on that and sort of the underlying macro employment assumption that underlies it?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that first of all we gave it after a great deal of discussion. I think you may be surprised how much discussion, but based on what we’re seeing we gave the guidance or the expectation, I should say, last year exactly at the same time. So, we fee
componenttext:
I think that first of all we gave it after a great deal of discussion. I think you may be surprised how much discussion, but based on what we’re seeing we gave the guidance or the expectation, I should say, last year exactly at the same time. So, we feel that given this time of the year, we have some visibility into what to expect and we are doing our planning for next year and have some visibility and we have a business that builds momentum. Our deferred balance by the end of this year will be significantly higher than a year ago. We expect deferred to be up year-over-year, if you couldn’t hear that, what James just said is, going into this year, our deferred balance was a little under, I think $300 million, about $305 million.
This year we plan on entering 2011, approximately $100 million better than that. So, that gives us quite a bit more momentum going into 2011 than we had going into this year, and the momentum of the business as I said before really is increasing around the world, and you couple that with the product that’s been delivered and are now taking hold with the customers, the products that we’ve already seen very strong indications of interest although we haven’t introduced them yet to the market, it gives us confidence that numbers in that range are within our grasp.
Now, I hedge all of this, all right, with the fact that if there is some sort of cataclysmic event in the world, if economies around the world go in reverse, again, in a significant way, these numbers most likely will not be achievable. But given the economy we have today, given the unemployment rates that we have today that will stabilize at these levels, we firmly believe we’ll able to get to these kind of numbers.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know you don’t build up your business based on sort of an unemployment rate expectation or anything like that, but basically what I’m hearing is sort of a stable economy like this, maybe the similar type of overall sort of employment growth that we
componenttext: I know you don’t build up your business based on sort of an unemployment rate expectation or anything like that, but basically what I’m hearing is sort of a stable economy like this, maybe the similar type of overall sort of employment growth that we’ve been seeing, is kind of what you’re baking in or sort of assuming for ‘11?

componenttext: That’s correct.
