headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you could talk a little bit about the pricing trends that you’re seeing in terms of postings and resume database, both in terms of the PRS product as well as the old product?
componenttext: If you could talk a little bit about the pricing trends that you’re seeing in terms of postings and resume database, both in terms of the PRS product as well as the old product?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think on total PRS, as we indicated, when we introduced the product, it is a premium price product, some premium to traditional classic search as we refer to it, and that pricing stability as I indicated in my comment is holding. We’re seeing more ado
componenttext:
I think on total PRS, as we indicated, when we introduced the product, it is a premium price product, some premium to traditional classic search as we refer to it, and that pricing stability as I indicated in my comment is holding. We’re seeing more adoption in the sense of customers seeing PRS is a methodology, to some degree, it is a change in how companies do search for talent, and it’s a longer term sell. It is not a sell that in one conversation happens for the most part, okay?
So, as customers are becoming more knowledgeable and are seeing more the value of the product and the benefits that it may bring, and as they’re listening more to what’s coming down the pike in terms of future products, precision search product predicated on the 6Sense technology, the momentum and the conversation is moving less to price and more to the benefits that the technology brings to the table.
So, that’s working well for us and based on what we’re seeing now, that’s most likely going to continue. If I caught off the correctly, with regard to posting, and call it, more traditional product, we’re not seeing any significant change. Obviously an individual customer, the price may go up or go down based on volume of what they’re purchasing et cetera. But as an overall matter across the board, things are pretty much even, prices are relatively stable, and maybe in a few cases I think we’re starting see some improvement.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And are you assuming for next year that pricing will stay basically stable or maybe increase a little bit or how you think about that?
componenttext: And are you assuming for next year that pricing will stay basically stable or maybe increase a little bit or how you think about that?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Based on what we’re seeing right now, we think things will remain fairly stable. Obviously, we can’t speak to, if we introduce new products what that pricing maybe and how that will put in, but obviously, it’s just a different market and we’ll see
componenttext: Based on what we’re seeing right now, we think things will remain fairly stable. Obviously, we can’t speak to, if we introduce new products what that pricing maybe and how that will put in, but obviously, it’s just a different market and we’ll see how it goes. But for the current products, current suite of products for the most part, I would say things will stay relatively stable. We’re not building anything into that 20% to 25% increase for price increases or anything of that sort.

componenttext: As Sal mentioned, in Q1 we got to merge the two sites together, so basically the traffic that’s currently going towards the Hotjobs site will go toward the Monster site and the seekers from the trough that you see on Yahoo’s homepage will go directly into the Monster site. The same thing for the employers, we are merging those sites together and merging the customers base together as well as the seekers together. So starting sometime in Q1 the experience will be a Monster experience along with some of the other changes we are currently making.

componenttext: Darko you type into HotJobs and then it will take you to Monster?

componenttext: Correct. So if you go to a trough, there is going to be a Monster there and if you click on where there’s currently HotJobs, there is going to be a Monster there. If you type HotJobs they will redirect you directly Monster. So according to the SCO [ph] or purposes or in the mean search engine if you go there it’s going to automatically direct you to Monster.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the integration, things are going quite well so far. We were able to keep, I believe, about 97% of the sales team during the first two weeks and they have not seen a lot of attrition at all. We have put together a good teaming policy and also
componenttext: In terms of the integration, things are going quite well so far. We were able to keep, I believe, about 97% of the sales team during the first two weeks and they have not seen a lot of attrition at all. We have put together a good teaming policy and also clear direction for the teams through Q4 as we work through how we integrate the two teams into one. We are doing that on a functional basis. So team by team, we are looking at what makes sense in moving forward and as Sal mentioned during his remarks, we are beginning to accelerate that looking at the success that we’ve had early on.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lise, do you want to comment a little bit on in terms of the training and how you are helping in bringing the two forces together?
componenttext: Lise, do you want to comment a little bit on in terms of the training and how you are helping in bringing the two forces together?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We started out when we first brought the teams together during some significant training. Every member of the HotJobs’ team went for at least one day of training. While they are still focusing on their products and as we bring the two teams togeth
componenttext: Sure. We started out when we first brought the teams together during some significant training. Every member of the HotJobs’ team went for at least one day of training. While they are still focusing on their products and as we bring the two teams together, we’ll put them through close to two solid weeks of training so that they become fully integrated. We are pretty excited about it. We consider this kind of a privilege to have such a great talent pipeline for our sales force. We’re focused on that. We’re focused on boarding them with lots of training and those teams are pretty exciting.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I ask one last question? Can you just break out the expectations between North America versus international as we look out to the guidance for both Q4s as well as for next year?
componenttext: Can I ask one last question? Can you just break out the expectations between North America versus international as we look out to the guidance for both Q4s as well as for next year?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not at this time. May be we’ll get closer to that when we give you the earnings I should say for Q4. But right now I don’t think we’re prepared for that. To be honest with you, given our mix and the changes in economies and political issues, etc., i
componenttext: Not at this time. May be we’ll get closer to that when we give you the earnings I should say for Q4. But right now I don’t think we’re prepared for that. To be honest with you, given our mix and the changes in economies and political issues, etc., in different countries around the world that we operate in, we do operate in 56 different countries, a number of them significant. It really would be very difficult to do that, but, overall, as I’ve said, the number is 20% to 25% above the cost of board.

componenttext: Hi. Thank you. I know you guys mentioned you’re not going to breakout HotJobs going forward, but I think in the past you had talked about maybe around 80 to 70 million in the revenue and 20 to 40 in EBITDA. I’m wondering if that still holds. If you can maybe help us out in terms of breaking out next year, is that 20% to 25% inclusive of HotJobs? What would it be exclusive?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The 20% to 25% is inclusive of HotJobs, and everything we see about the business and about the acquisition gives us no reason to change the numbers we’ve talked about historically.
componenttext: The 20% to 25% is inclusive of HotJobs, and everything we see about the business and about the acquisition gives us no reason to change the numbers we’ve talked about historically.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to give you a little color, when you think about this 20% to 25% we think of it as approximately 20% of it is Monster. On the high side 5% would be HotJob. We just can’t account for it, in terms of showing how much is the contribution among us and
componenttext:
Just to give you a little color, when you think about this 20% to 25% we think of it as approximately 20% of it is Monster. On the high side 5% would be HotJob. We just can’t account for it, in terms of showing how much is the contribution among us and the other, as times goes on. And as sales forces are converging and as sales people of HotJobs and sales people of Monster are working together to present the solution, an overall solution to a customer it gets very difficult to say how much is HotJob versus how much will be Monster. I can tell you that this is very occurring.
There is one example I have in mind right now there was a large staffing company transactions where there was business that have been done with that customer both from HotJobs as well as from the Monster’s side. Thankfully, the overall transaction when you added the historical HotJobs and historical Monster the new transaction was a bit higher in total, but exactly what you could attribute to HotJobs and what you could attribute to Monster really gets very vague and even we would give you numbers, it really would be meaningless.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We definitely see it as a source of traffic for us, and as a tool for the seekers. We launched an iPhone App very recently, iPad is next, Android is following that fairly quickly. Clearly, in addition to being a tool for seekers and the employers, we’re
componenttext: We definitely see it as a source of traffic for us, and as a tool for the seekers. We launched an iPhone App very recently, iPad is next, Android is following that fairly quickly. Clearly, in addition to being a tool for seekers and the employers, we’re also looking at the opportunities to monetize, from the advertising standpoint, those channels. So, we see it as a very important future channel and we want to figure out how do we best monetize that tool and the Apps that we launched at this moment have received a large of number of people downloading them and we plan to, almost every quarter, launching new app for one of these platforms.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just wanted to ask two questions here, if I could. First on the internet advertising segment, there has been a lot of commentary out of some of the education companies, which I believe is a decent size customer for IAF. Can you talk about how big tha
componenttext:
Yes. Just wanted to ask two questions here, if I could. First on the internet advertising segment, there has been a lot of commentary out of some of the education companies, which I believe is a decent size customer for IAF. Can you talk about how big that is? And then those companies have talked about cutting back and some of the lead spending that they’ll be doing, so have you seen that or is that a source of risk as you look forward?
And then secondly, just Sal maybe qualitatively, you gave one example of the conversations you’re having with clients as you’re trying to shift them from Hotjobs to kind of the combined bases, but what’s been the retention of that client base and their ability to bring the pricing up relative to Hotjobs old pricing, just maybe qualitative how that’s meeting your expectations post the deal.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, we’d be going to the first part of your question. The decline or the concern regarding the education activity is not phenomenon of Q3, it’s been building throughout the year and really accelerated, I guess, in Q2 and has continu
componenttext:
I think, first of all, we’d be going to the first part of your question. The decline or the concern regarding the education activity is not phenomenon of Q3, it’s been building throughout the year and really accelerated, I guess, in Q2 and has continued into Q3. So we’ve been preparing and looking for as business changes, as the methodology changes, as the concerns change for us to change with it and be ready to move into different form, different client base, et cetera, in addition to our traditional ones to broaden ourselves and diversify in the education space.
Overall, our education revenue has stayed relatively flat to slightly improved and I mean, very slightly which given the turmoil that’s been in the industry, particularly on the full profits side, we feel very good about that. Now, I understand that this coming Monday or Tuesday, the government is going to release more guidance on what’s involved or what they want in terms of governance on lead generation and quality of candidate in essence.
We’re obviously very keen to see that and understand it but we are really prepared and this is something we’ve been tackling and dealing with for the past six months I would say roughly. I think I’m in a fairly good position. We’ll see what the doctor, in fact, has to say and then we’ll continue to maneuver around it.
With regard to pricing and HotJobs, et cetera, right now the discussion has been centered much more on the solution, the quality of the product mix, and a full-blown solution, and most importantly, we haven’t seen any significant departures of customers, etc., and what we have seen and in terms of pricing, the Monster pricing basically continuing, as I said, before stabilizing and staying stable, and for the most part, the HotJobs pricing either improving where we’re able to introduce higher quality products or more products, different products or staying the same.
We’re certainly not seeing a deterioration on the Monster’s side or the HotJobs side, all right. In tandem, they seem to be moving along evenly, if you will. I caution and it’s a risk in the transaction, we thought it’s a risk, and all of Tim’s numbers, et cetera, that we allowed for, okay, I think fairly conservatively, when we entered the transaction that there could be some breakage, but we haven’t seen that yet, but it’s early.
It’s only been two months or so now since the closing of the transaction, and as next month, next few quarters. As of right now, where we don’t have any serious concern. We’re watching it carefully. It’s something we’ve been on guard for since conceptualizing the transaction to be honest with you. But it’s not something that surprised us or hurt us to this point in time.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and thank you for joining us on Monster Worldwide's Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call. We will have formal remarks from Sal Iannuzzi, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Yates, Executive Vice President and Chief Financi
componenttext:
Good evening, and thank you for joining us on Monster Worldwide's Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call. We will have formal remarks from Sal Iannuzzi, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Yates, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition to Sal and Tim, several members of our executive management team are available to answer your questions during the Q&A part of the call. They are Darko Dejanovic, CIO and Head of Product; Ted Gilvar, Chief Marketing Officer; James Langrock, Chief Accounting Officer; Michael Miller, General Counsel; Art O'Donnell, Head of Global Services; Kathy Paladino, Head of North American Sales; Lise Poulos, Chief Administrative Officer; and Mark Stoever, Corporate Development and Strategic Alliances.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that except for historical information, the statements made during this call constitute forward-looking statements under applicable securities laws. Such forward-looking statements involve certain risks and uncertainties, including statements regarding the company’s strategic direction, prospects and future results. Certain factors, including factors outside of our control, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements, including economic and other conditions in the markets in which we operate, risks associated with acquisitions or dispositions, competition and the other risks discussed in our Form 10-K and our other filings made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Sal for his comments.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lori. Good evening, and thank you all for joining us for our third quarter conference call.During the quarter, we continue to build momentum with strong bookings growth across all geographies and within our major vertical markets. My comments
componenttext:
Thank you, Lori. Good evening, and thank you all for joining us for our third quarter conference call.
During the quarter, we continue to build momentum with strong bookings growth across all geographies and within our major vertical markets. My comments will focus on Monster alone unless otherwise noted. Tim will comment on Monster and HotJobs. In the quarter we reported bookings of $229 million, a year-over-year increase of 23%, exceeded the high end of our guidance despite the negative currency impact. In-line revenue of $223 million, in-line earnings per share of $0.01. $300 million in deferred revenue, a sequential increase of $20 million. 
Our ability to achieve this financial result is based on two factors. First, despite the continuing uncertainty of the global economy, there have been signs of recovery. And second, our customers are recognizing the effectiveness of our enhanced portfolio of recruitment solutions. We believe that our global market reach, combined with our value-added solutions, are unrivaled in the marketplace and are fueling our strong bookings growth. I want to talk first about our global reach, why it is so significant and how it can be enhanced through the Yahoo! Traffic deal and HotJobs acquisition. Next, I'll talk about our enhanced service offering, highlighting power resume search and our Career Ad Network. Then I will discuss the performance benefits when you combine scale with the precision of our innovative products. Lastly, I'll wrap up with comments on the global economy and throw in some expensive future performance.
Let me say a few words about our global reach. Including incremental fabric resulting from the Yahoo! Traffic deal, more than 47 million people now visit Monster and Monster partner site on a monthly basis. Adding in our Career Ad Network, we are able to reach approximately 117 million active and passive job seekers on a monthly basis. 
With HotJobs, we now have over 1,000 newspaper alliances with local presence in all 50 states. These alliances are important to our customers as they significantly expand Monster's local reach. Monster owns global language sites in 56 countries and has the number one or two market share position in most of the developed markets. 
We have recently launched a Monster site in Brazil and are encouraged by the early results. One of the primary objectives of the HotJobs and Yahoo! transactions was to provide us additional seeker and client scale in the U.S. Though we have only been operating together for a short time, the integration is going well and we are very pleased with the performance and commitment of the HotJobs team. 
Tim will discuss in his comments that the financial results are consistent with our expectations. We are on track to launch the integrated website in the first quarter of 2011. And we are accelerating the integration of our sales team so that all clients fully understand the powerful value proposition which the combination of HotJobs and Monster provide. 
But scale and global reach alone are not sufficient. When that scale is combined with the precision of our 6Sense technology and our unique and customizable product solutions, we have a far superior value proposition for our clients. I'd like to update you on two of those solutions. Our resume search or PRS and Career Ad Network or CAN. 
In Q3, PRS accounted for approximately 45% of search license bookings in North America. In the United Kingdom, PRS was available for the first full quarter and accounted for approximately 40% of the search license bookings. 
We recently introduced PRS in France, and while it's been just a few weeks, the significant customer interest and feedback has been positive. Our beta test in Australia is underway and we are on track for a commercial launch early next year. In 2011, we plan to launch PRS in additional countries around the world. 
As you know, we are maintaining a significant price premium over classic and we are gratified that so many of our clients see its value. Given our results for PRS to date, we believe it will be the predominant search tool used by our customers. None of our competitors offers a comparable product. 
CAN is the industry's largest recruitment focus ad network. It distributes our customer job advertisements across a broad array of targeted websites in a very effective way of expanding our fine pool of active and passive seekers. Our customers who use CAN generally in conjunction with the traditional posting products, find a substantial almost double increase in their views and applies. And we find we gain incremental revenue and market share compared to simply offering a traditional job posting. 
Among our major competitors, only HotJobs had a comparable product offered and we are now able to offer our clients the combined power of both Monster and Yahoo! networks. We are executing on a global strategy by fully developing 10 in 14 of our top global markets. 
As a result of the combination of unsurpassed scale and product solution offerings, we believe we offer our clients a superior return on their investments when buying from Monster. This is beginning to be evident in our results. 
On a global basis, our renewal rates and our rate of acquisition of new customers is substantially improved and more customers are buying more of our products offered. In North America and Europe over the first nine months, we booked business with 20,000 more clients, a 16% increase over last year. 
On a global basis, bookings were up 23% before HotJobs. Asia was up 36%, positively impacted by 4% of currency translation. North America was up 31%. Europe was up 17% after absorbing 11% negative impact from currency. 
The bookings of our combined career business increased 28% and accounted for 86% of our total bookings. 
Bookings in our IAF business, which accounted for the remaining 14%, were flat compared to last year, but up sequentially in line with prior year's experience. The flat year-over-year trend was due largely to the reduction of spend from the on-services who have cut the recruitment budget. 
We are very encouraged by the clients' reception for all the work we have done over the past three years and our primary objective is to fully execute on the delivery of our value proposition to our global client base.
PRS and CAN are helping us meet the recruitment needs of our customers better than any of our competitors, but we are, by no means finished. For example, we are continuing to develop new products based on our 6Sense technology. For example, our 6Sense enterprise suite is a talent management solution that enables our customers to manage their entire resume base, selected from multiple sources. In addition to the piles with MRINetwork we mentioned on our last quarterly earnings call, we have had over 100 conversations with potential customers who have expressed serious interest in the product capability and we are working with key potential clients to refine the product. We plan to launch this product family in the second quarter of 2011.
I would now like to take a few moments to provide some historical concepts on the macro factors which have influenced our business over the past several years and how we currently see the economy, the job market, and most importantly, Monster's business evolving for the remainder of 2010 and 2011. 
Before 2008, it was generally agreed that companies were likely to face an increasing global skill shortage over the next several decades. Demographic trends such as the aging population, increasing job specialization and the impact of technology drove the belief that talents would be an increasing demand and it will be more difficult to match the right candidate to the right job. 
But then came the financial meltdown and the great recession. Companies around the world touched that. They did not replace voluntary attrition, which itself, slowed down because most employees who had jobs wanted to hold on to them. And all budgets including recruiting were flat. Of course, the combination of these factors had a direct and dramatic effect on Monster. Our bookings began to decline on a year-over-year basis in the second quarter of 2008 and bottomed at a 46% year-over-year decline in the first quarter of 2009. 
Starting in the third quarter of 2009 and through the middle of 2010 business began to stabilize. During this difficult time period we've remained committed to our investment in technology and product innovation. A year ago, in October, we highlighted the economic cross currents and the unusually high degree of economic and business uncertainty, which was affecting us and our clients. At that time, we laid out a financial framework for 2010, which was later confirmed for our annual guidance. 
We are pleased that Monster is currently on track to meet or exceed that guidance. Bookings for the fourth quarter are currently expected to increase 20% to 24% bringing year-over-year growth to 20% to 21%. This compares favorably to our bookings guidance range of 15% to 20% for the year. 
Because of the fall off in deferred revenue, we knew that revenue growth would lag bookings growth, and therefore, we guided revenue to plus or minus 2%. Our current year-over-year growth for the fourth quarter is currently expected to be in the range of 13% to 17%, bringing the full year to flat to down 2% compared to 2009. Our initial outlook on operating expense contemplated a 3% to 6% growth year-over-year. We knew that we wanted to make some incremental investments in our franchise and our people while our business was beginning to rebound. We have been able to make most of those investments while holding operating expense essentially flat or up 1% in 2010. 
For EPS, inclusive of a modest contribution from HotJobs, we have now at our expected loss on a per share basis in the range of a loss of $0.05 to $0.09. While we are pleased to have better exceeded our financial parameters during 2010, we fully expect that the profitability pay off from the investments we have been making will begin to be harvested in the quarters ahead. As we look forward, we are continuing to live in a political and macroeconomic environment which is highly uncertain, and unemployment continues to be suddenly high. But despite those uncertainties, our business on a global basis has continued to firm throughout the year. 
Clients around the world are beginning to realize that they need to increase their staffing levels and that job churn is beginning to pick up. So our clients are working harder to retain and attract talent. At the same time, hope for profitability and liquidity has continued to improve, and companies have the budget dollars to spend if they choose to. 
Our clients are beginning to refocus on the talent gap, and Monster is ideally situated to capitalize on that trend, even in this trepid economic environment we are experiencing today. In an environment with global economies continuing to show moderate GDP growth and where unemployment rates continue to be slow to improve, we believe Monster will produce strong financial results. As a primary indication for 2011, bookings, including HotJobs, are expected to grow in the 20% to 25% range year-over-year, which was on top of the 23% to 24% growth expected in 2010. 
Based on our outlook for bookings in the fourth quarter, we expect to end the year with a substantially higher deferred revenue balance, which gives us a great start for 2011.
With expected bookings growth in the range of 20% to 25%, revenue is expected to increase at a similar rate. We remain committed to longer-term operating margin potential of 25%. During 2011 we conservatively believe that at least 50% of incremental revenue will drop to the operating income line. As a reminder, operating expenses increased sequentially from Q4 into Q1. And while we expect to see that trend in Q1 2011, we currently do not anticipate as much as the sequential increase as we experienced in the first quarter of 2010. We are also currently expect to be modestly profitable in the first quarter of 2011. We will provide guidance for 2011 when we release our fourth quarter earnings. Now I'd like to turn it over to Tim for additional financial detail.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sal and good evening everyone. As we did last quarter, I will be using slides to guide our conversation. Before turning to the first slide, I would like to point out that this quarter, we are breaking out the impact of HotJobs and we are updati
componenttext:
Thank you, Sal and good evening everyone. As we did last quarter, I will be using slides to guide our conversation. Before turning to the first slide, I would like to point out that this quarter, we are breaking out the impact of HotJobs and we are updating our guidance for the fourth quarter and full year to clearly demonstrate its impact. 
Year-over-year and sequential percentage changes shown on the slides compare Monster's results excluding HotJobs. Turning to Slide 1 for Q3, pro forma income statement. Revenue was $231 million. Excluding $8 million from HotJobs, revenue was $223 million, up 4% sequentially and year-over-year. This result was at the midpoint of our guidance range. 
Operating expense was $225 million. Excluding $6 million from HotJobs, OpEx was $219 million, up 3% sequentially and 4% year-over-year. Combined revenue was negatively impacted by $4 million of currency translation while operating expenses were favorably impacted by $3 million for a net negative currency impact of $1 million on a year-over-year basis. 
Interest expense was $1.6 million. Equity loss primarily reflecting our investment in CareerOne Australia was $873,000. Net income of $2 million includes $1 million from HotJobs.
Earnings per share of $0.02 includes $0.01 per share from HotJobs. Excluding HotJobs, EPS came in at the higher end of our negative $0.02 to positive $0.02 per share guidance.
Slide 2 is our GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation. The larger reconciling items were $8.6 million expense on the office in general line representing costs associated with the HotJobs transaction, primarily legal and professional service fees. We continue to forecast the total of $30 million in onetime acquisition and integration costs related to HotJobs. To date, we have incurred $18 million of the $30 million and expect to have the great majority of these onetime costs behind us by the end of the fourth quarter, $1.8 million revenue adjustment representing from purchase accounting related to the acquisition. In total, pro forma adjustments were negative $7.7 million after-tax in the quarter.
Slide 3 is Q3 2010 pro forma expense trends slide. The breakdown of expenses was the following. Total salary and related expense was $119 million. Excluding $2 million from HotJobs, salary and related was up 2% from the prior quarter, reflecting an increase in stock based compensation. Marketing expense was $52 million. Excluding $3.3 million from HotJobs, marketing was up 3% sequentially as a result of higher spending in China, Germany and the U.K. and to support a higher level of revenue in IAF. Office and general expense was $55 million. Excluding $745,000 from HotJobs, O&G was up 4% from the prior quarter. Total headcount in the quarter was 5,792 including 207 employees from HotJobs. 
Slide 4 is bookings and revenue trend. Combined bookings increased 26%. Excluding HotJobs, Monster's bookings increased 23% compared to last year. The strength of our year-over-year bookings growth was broadly spread across our geographies and channels. Asia, the smallest absolute dollar contributor, experienced the fastest growth at 36% and was positively impacted by 4% in currency. Within Asia, Career remains our strongest contributor on a percentage growth basis with bookings up 44%. We also experienced strong bookings growth in China, 32%; and India, 30%. North America, excluding bookings from HotJobs, produced the second strongest percentage growth at 31%. Overall, we experienced strong performance from our enterprise clients, both in our field and telesales channels. We also saw strong results from staffing, e-commerce and the government channel. 
Europe region increased 17%, negatively impacted by 11% of currency translation with all major current countries experiencing bookings growth. During the third quarter, Sweden remained our largest percentage gain contributor, up 45%. Importantly, Germany's bookings continued to build momentum with an increase of 26%, joining France, Belgium, Switzerland with double-digit growth. While growth in the U.K. and the Netherlands has lagged the other European countries, business in both markets has definitely begun to pick up and we are expecting strong year-over-year growth in both markets in Q4.
Slide 5 shows the results of our operating segments. For the purpose of this discussion, I will focus on the non-GAAP results inclusive of HotJobs. As discussed, combined revenue on a year-over-year basis is up 7%. Within that, our combined Careers business was up 8%, with North American Careers up 15% and the International segment up 2%. 
The revenue of the International segment was negatively impacted by 5% of currency adjustment and by the fact that the economic recovery in some key markets lagged the rest of the global recovery. For example, you will recall that bookings in Germany were essentially flat in the first quarter of this year and bookings in the United Kingdom have continued to lag. These lower growth rates in bookings then flow through revenue over the next several quarters. IRS revenue was up 1%, and Sal has commented on the trends impacting that segment. 
Our combined operating margin was 2.4% during the quarter and was comprised of the 19% operating margin in North America, a negative 6.4% operating margin in the International segment. The margin of the International segment is negatively impacted by the comparably later ramp up in revenue I noted above and by the fact that the segment absorbs our continuing investment in China and developing markets. As we have previously commented, we believe that both China and the developing markets represent substantial median-term opportunities for the company. And we also believe that the International segment will produce very attractive operating margins as revenue in our more-developed markets ramps up. 
IAF had an operating margin of 5.5%. We had continued to maintain most of the cost structure to handle a significantly larger level of revenue, and we point out that a relatively small amount of incremental revenue has a significant impact on the operating margin of the IAF segment. Finally, corporate expenses were $11.6 million, representing 5% of operating margin. Corporate expenses may have some minor variability from quarter-to-quarter, but will reduce as a percentage of revenue as revenue rebounds.
Slide 6 is key balance sheet and cash flow items. And most of the significant cash flow items for the quarter were consistent with our expectation. GAAP EBITDA was $24.6 million, pro forma EBITDA was $35.6 million, a 15% EBITDA margin. Net cash provided by operations was $18.6 million compared to $11.8 million in last year's third quarter. Capital expenditures was $16.2 million. 
Deferred revenue, including HotJobs, was $313 million. Excluding HotJobs, deferred revenue was $299 million, a sequential increase of approximately $20 million from the prior quarter. We expect that deferred revenue will be significantly higher at year-end. Our net cash was $36 million and our total liquidity comprised of gross cash and credit available was $259 million.
Summarizing the quarter, our strategy is working, our financial results are meeting or surpassing the expectations we have laid out, and this is the first quarter since Q1 of 2008 when bookings, revenue and deferred revenue all have been up on a year-over-year basis. Sal has already provided guidance for Q4 and the year for Monster on a stand-alone basis, and I will build on that guidance by adding the expected impact of HotJobs. 
As Sal noted, we are moving quickly to integrate the HotJobs segment, and going forward, it would be increasingly difficult to provide meaningful stand-alone financials. So while we fully expect to report to you on our success with the HotJobs client base, we do not intend to separately breakout its income statement starting with the fourth quarter.
Slide 7 summarizes our fourth quarter guidance. We currently expect that Monster's bookings will be up between 20% to 24%, and HotJobs will have bookings of between $18 million and $22 million. This results in a combined bookings range of $328 million to $342 million, a 27% to 32% year-over-year growth. Monster revenue will be up 13% to 17%, and HotJobs will be between $18 million and $22 million, resulting in a combined fourth quarter revenue of $258 million to $272 million, a 21% to 28% year-over-year growth. 
Combined fourth quarter earnings per share will be in the range of $0.04 to $0.08.
Slide 8 is the result in full-year guidance. We currently anticipate that bookings
[Audio Gap]
a 23% to 24% increase. Revenue excluding HotJobs will be $893 million to $903 million flat to down 2%. Including HotJobs, revenue will be $919 million to $933 million, a 1% to 3% increase. Including HotJobs, EPS for the year would be minus $0.09 to minus $0.05 range. Now I would like to turn the call back to Sal.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. It is clear that the investments we are making to enhance our scale and improve our products are gaining traction with our customers. We are looking forward to a strong Q4 and to a strong and profitable 2011. We are moving in the right direct
componenttext: Thanks, Tim. It is clear that the investments we are making to enhance our scale and improve our products are gaining traction with our customers. We are looking forward to a strong Q4 and to a strong and profitable 2011. We are moving in the right direction. We will continue to focus on penetrating our customer universe with the best-in-class offering and we will continue to win where it counts the most, in the clients office. Before we take questions, I want to thank our customers, employees and shareholders for their ongoing support, and we firmly intend to reward you for that support. Operator?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the bookings number, also, obviously, very good in the third quarter with pretty strong momentum heading into 4Q and 2011. Just wondering if you can give us some more color on what's driving the bookings strength, and also, the visibility, just in the
componenttext: In the bookings number, also, obviously, very good in the third quarter with pretty strong momentum heading into 4Q and 2011. Just wondering if you can give us some more color on what's driving the bookings strength, and also, the visibility, just in the context of generally soft global macro labor data?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I'll take the shot first, and I'm sure Tim and maybe others have -- will add to it. I think, first of all, while economies still aren't as strong as any of us would like to see them around the world, they are picking up. The momentum, clearly, in
componenttext:
I think I'll take the shot first, and I'm sure Tim and maybe others have -- will add to it. I think, first of all, while economies still aren't as strong as any of us would like to see them around the world, they are picking up. The momentum, clearly, in Europe, the United States, North America and Asia is significantly more positive than it was a year ago. If you look at even the Monster MEI reports, you'll see that in virtually every industry, whether it be in Europe or in North America, and then our MEI in India shows a significant growth year-over-year, as I said, virtually across every industry. So while economies are as strong as we like them, they are gaining strength. In addition to that, I think that our investments, what we've been working on for the past several years, are really starting to take hold with our customers. While we still have work to do and by no means of stopping, I think from what we've built and what customers are seeing as us providing solutions rather than just transactional support is really taking hold, and I think that's working in our favor. And I think it's taking market share away from our competitors. So I think, really, the bottom line is the combination of both the economy around the world improving, as well as the fact that Monster and its products, its service, the talents of our sales forces, the investments we made in our sales forces et cetera are all coming together to produce better results. And I think that it gives us confidence that those results will continue throughout 2011. 
Just a little bit more color on what's happening, most recently what we're seeing. A year ago, it was very hard to find customers who were planning major recruitment drives, most of which you've read in the paper and what we were seeing is many customers were talking about layoffs, some of them in the thousands of people. Right now, what we're starting to see is customers, there's about half a dozen or so that I think --  over the past two, three weeks, all of which are interested and are planning major recruitment campaigns in different areas of their business in the coming year in the field of technology, in the field of -- just across-the-board in a number of industries. And the recruitment efforts that go into the thousands of people per company. So we are encouraged by that. That's something that we have not seen in a while, certainly not on that scale, and that's just one observation or one example, if you will, of what appears to be going on out there. But I also mentioned PRS in my comments. 45% or so in the U.S., 40% in the U.K. is how resume search sells in the search area at a premium price. Because customers realize the benefit that, that service or that product brings to the table. So it's really a combination of things.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Huber with Access 342.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Talk about getting props back to a mid-20s EBITDA margin long term, I just wonder, if the economy continued to plug along here, roughly at the same rate, how many years do you think it would take to get to that? And then my other question I have, if I cou
componenttext: Talk about getting props back to a mid-20s EBITDA margin long term, I just wonder, if the economy continued to plug along here, roughly at the same rate, how many years do you think it would take to get to that? And then my other question I have, if I could is, when I look at CareerBuilder's numbers like a net post maybe had an up 9% to 10% revenue increases latest quarter here and I compare it to your number, up 4% to 7% with or without HotJobs, I'm just wondering, when you talk about market share gains, what data you are comparing there, please?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, and I'll start and I know Tim will definitely add to this. Revenue, I don't believe, is the current measure of the business because it's really a much more of a lagging indicator. I think what's current and what's showing the momentum of the
componenttext: First of all, and I'll start and I know Tim will definitely add to this. Revenue, I don't believe, is the current measure of the business because it's really a much more of a lagging indicator. I think what's current and what's showing the momentum of the business, clearly, is bookings. And based on what we're seeing, the conversations in the customer's office, the movement of customers, customers coming back to Monster that haven't dealt with us in sometime, the fact that we have 20,000 new customers this year versus last. Those customers are not buying for the first time in this industry. They're coming from somewhere else that they bought before. So I think that we are taking market share. And its not just a CareerBuilder excise, I think we're taking market share from CareerBuilder. I think we're having some impact on the Dices of the world, if you will. I think we're having impact overseas on some of our competitors there, for example, Stepstone in Germany and Eastern Europe for that matter. So I think it really cuts a very broad swap.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, did you say EBITDA margin? We're talking about operating margin. I couldn't quite hear the question, but in any event...
componenttext: I think, did you say EBITDA margin? We're talking about operating margin. I couldn't quite hear the question, but in any event...

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I thought you were talking about EBITDA margin impact to the mid-20s, eventually. I was curious how long you thought it might take to get back the economy.
componenttext: Yes, I thought you were talking about EBITDA margin impact to the mid-20s, eventually. I was curious how long you thought it might take to get back the economy.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've been talking about operating margin at getting to 25%. And we think that what we've been saying all along is that the company has significant operating leverage because of the investments we've made and because of the business model. We're saying fo
componenttext: We've been talking about operating margin at getting to 25%. And we think that what we've been saying all along is that the company has significant operating leverage because of the investments we've made and because of the business model. We're saying for 2011 now that bookings and revenue can grow in the range of 20% to 25%, and that at least 50% of that incremental revenue drops to the bottom line, depending on where you come in, in that range on the bookings and exactly how much of it we dropped to the bottom line, you're making a significant step in the direction obviously back in the direction of significant profitability. If you extrapolated that just mathematically, you're talking about 2.5 to three years. But I'm not forecasting that in terms of exactly precisely because we want to continue to look at the portfolio of businesses we have. But at the minimum, and Sal will add to this, we're going to return at least 50% of that to the bottom line next year.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that -- look, we're all a little bit gun shy given what's happened the past couple of years and what we've seen. But given where the market, what we're seeing in the marketplace now, given the comments I just finished making with regard to the mom
componenttext: I think that -- look, we're all a little bit gun shy given what's happened the past couple of years and what we've seen. But given where the market, what we're seeing in the marketplace now, given the comments I just finished making with regard to the momentum we see around the world, et cetera, we feel we're going to be conservative and we feel that our estimate for increasing revenue next year in the range of 20% to 25% is certainly within the range of what we can do. I think we're going to continue to watch our expenses very closely. It's what we've always done and we will continue to do that. We will spend some money when we feel we've earned it, but not until that time. And we intend to bring margin and profitability to our shareholders just as quickly as we can without sacrificing the future. And so I think that it's hard to forecast right now, from where we sit today, to forecast when we will be at a 25% margin. But having said that, we intend to get there and we intend to get there as fast as we can. And I think that's going to happen. Because of the investments we've made, they are going to pay off now. We have a significant confidence that, that's going to happen. And if we prudently watch the expenses, we'll get there. Now I hate to be negative, but if the economy should, in the middle of next year or at some point in time, take another nose dive around the world, then I think that the effect on Monster will be a little bit more muted than it was this last time because of the products and the products that we plan on introducing in the coming months. But I think that it will still, obviously, have an impact. But whether it's, as Tim said, in 2.5 years or whether it's in the next year and a half, it's very difficult to predict right now. But I think that we are on the right track, and I think you can do the numbers. Even if we return next year a 20% to 25% increase in revenue and only half of that, and that's a conservative number, goes to the bottom line, I think you can do the arithmetic and see there's quite a transition from where we were this year.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to answer your first question, literally, if you were doing EBITDA margin, probably be a year and a half to two years.
componenttext: And to answer your first question, literally, if you were doing EBITDA margin, probably be a year and a half to two years.

componenttextpreview: Returning back to profitability, the tax rate that I would use is probably around 35%. Interest would be, I would say, in the $1.5 million to $2 million, probably a little more in the first half of the year. And then as we're generating cash flow, we'll p
componenttext: Returning back to profitability, the tax rate that I would use is probably around 35%. Interest would be, I would say, in the $1.5 million to $2 million, probably a little more in the first half of the year. And then as we're generating cash flow, we'll pay down the debt, so that will start reducing. But I would use $1.5 million to $2 million of interest from a modeling standpoint.

componenttext: $1.5 million per quarter. $1 million to $2 million. I would say, earlier on, it's probably $2 million, then later out, it's probably about $1.5 million.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we do. And as you know, we announced the deal. This was for all of North America. So we are also operating up in Canada. But we've started a variety of discussions within Europe, and also, in one of our new emerging markets throughout Latin America. S
componenttext: No, we do. And as you know, we announced the deal. This was for all of North America. So we are also operating up in Canada. But we've started a variety of discussions within Europe, and also, in one of our new emerging markets throughout Latin America. So with the agreement with Yahoo!, we established sort of the ground rules and the profits by which we would reach agreement in any of the markets that make sense. And we are actively exploring many of them already.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In light of your revenue expectations for '11, any preliminary thoughts on headcount additions year-over-year? And then secondly, on international, Tim, you mentioned it's a big opportunity if you can turn it around. Any updated color on kind of where the
componenttext: In light of your revenue expectations for '11, any preliminary thoughts on headcount additions year-over-year? And then secondly, on international, Tim, you mentioned it's a big opportunity if you can turn it around. Any updated color on kind of where the losses are and where the most rapid improvements could come from in '11 and '12?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: There were two reasons why the operating margin is lagging now. One is the fact that the gap between the bookings growth is not flowing through the revenue as it will next year. So we're operating the business on the headcount in there with a much lower l
componenttext: There were two reasons why the operating margin is lagging now. One is the fact that the gap between the bookings growth is not flowing through the revenue as it will next year. So we're operating the business on the headcount in there with a much lower level of revenue than we're currently achieving in bookings. So that will flow through next year with no increase in headcount. The second factor is investments in China and the developing markets, which I categorized as medium-term opportunities. And what the major developing markets we're talking about are Eastern Europe and Brazil, we are doing quite well in terms of all the metrics we watch. The results of those are improving, would consider to be improving into 2011, offset by, perhaps, some additional spend. But the net of all of that will be an improvement in the investment next year. And in terms of when we think they'll break even, Sal, do you want ...

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that some will begin to break even probably the latter half of next year, and others going forward into 2012. The larger ones, the larger investments, China, perhaps, I think would be the latter half of next year. And Brazil, which is another -- n
componenttext: I think that some will begin to break even probably the latter half of next year, and others going forward into 2012. The larger ones, the larger investments, China, perhaps, I think would be the latter half of next year. And Brazil, which is another -- nowhere near the investment of China, but certainly a very interesting investment, probably in 2012. But overall, I think, the portfolio, what we call developing countries or emerging markets, I think by the middle to the end of next year, roughly we'll start to show results overall, as either flat to positive.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of headcount, nothing really that significant. We always add some sales people as we see opportunity and we can correlate that as we see the bookings develop.
componenttext: And in terms of headcount, nothing really that significant. We always add some sales people as we see opportunity and we can correlate that as we see the bookings develop.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct. We had demands, as you might imagine, after making the reductions we've made and watching the pocketbook very, very closely over the past two years. So certainly, demands within the company requests for more people. And in isolated cases,
componenttext: That's correct. We had demands, as you might imagine, after making the reductions we've made and watching the pocketbook very, very closely over the past two years. So certainly, demands within the company requests for more people. And in isolated cases, as we've been doing throughout this year, we have added some staff very selectively and strategically, and that will continue into next year. But we do not believe that it is of the scale, the size that would certainly offset the kind of expectation that we gave you a little while ago.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question, I just wanted to talk a little bit more about the 20% to 25% bookings growth expectation for 2011. Certainly encouraging. I guess I'm somewhat surprised that you're giving that kind of expectation this early on, even before you
componenttext: I guess the first question, I just wanted to talk a little bit more about the 20% to 25% bookings growth expectation for 2011. Certainly encouraging. I guess I'm somewhat surprised that you're giving that kind of expectation this early on, even before your sort of fourth quarter seasonal recontracting period. Just want to get the sense for sort of the visibility, your conviction in that number, what gives you the confidence to deliver on it and sort of the underlying macro employment assumption that underlies it?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, we gave it after a great deal of discussion. I think you may be surprised how much discussion. But based on what we're seeing -- based on the facts -- by the way, we gave the guidance, or the expectation I should say, at last year a
componenttext: I think, first of all, we gave it after a great deal of discussion. I think you may be surprised how much discussion. But based on what we're seeing -- based on the facts -- by the way, we gave the guidance, or the expectation I should say, at last year after virtually exactly at the same time. So we feel that given this time of year, we have some visibility into what to expect and we are doing our planning for next year and have some visibility, and we have a business that builds momentum. Our deferred balance by the end of this year will be significantly higher than a year ago. We expect deferred to be up year-over-year by...

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Including HotJobs, it'll be close to $400 million, or $100 million more in the year.
componenttext: Including HotJobs, it'll be close to $400 million, or $100 million more in the year.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you couldn't here that, what James just said is, going into this year, our deferred balance was a little under, I think, $300 million. About $305 million. This year we plan on entering 2011 approximately $100 million better than that. So that gives us
componenttext: If you couldn't here that, what James just said is, going into this year, our deferred balance was a little under, I think, $300 million. About $305 million. This year we plan on entering 2011 approximately $100 million better than that. So that gives us quite a bit more momentum going into 2011 than we had going into this year. And the momentum of the business, as I've said before, really is increasing around the world. And you couple that with the products that has been delivered and are now are talking hold with the customers, the products that we've already seen very strong indications of interest, although we haven't introduced them yet to the market. It gives us confidence that numbers in that range are within our grasp. Now I hedge all of them with the fact that if there is some sort of product loose make event in the world, if economies around the world go in reverse again in a significant way, these numbers most likely will not be achievable. But given the economy we have today, given the unemployment rates that we have today, that stabilize at these levels, we firmly believe we'll be able to get to these kind of numbers.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

componenttext: I know you don't build up your business based on sort of on unemployment rate expectation or anything like that. But basically, what I'm hearing is sort of a stable economy like this maybe the similar type of overall sort of employment growth that we've been seeing is kind of what you're baking in or sort of assuming for '11.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you could talk a little bit about the pricing trends that you're seeing in terms of postings and resume database both in terms of the PRS product as well as the old product?
componenttext: If you could talk a little bit about the pricing trends that you're seeing in terms of postings and resume database both in terms of the PRS product as well as the old product?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think on PRS, as we indicated, when we introduced the product, it is a premium priced product, something premium to traditional or plastic search as we refer to it. And that pricing stability, as I indicated in my comment, is holding. We're seeing more
componenttext: I think on PRS, as we indicated, when we introduced the product, it is a premium priced product, something premium to traditional or plastic search as we refer to it. And that pricing stability, as I indicated in my comment, is holding. We're seeing more adoption in the sense of customers seeing that -- PRS is a methodology. To some degree, it is a change in how companies do search for some talents and it's a longer-term sale. It is not a sale that in one conversation happens for the most part. And so as customers are becoming more knowledgeable and are seeing more the value of the product and the benefits that it may bring and as they're listening more to what's coming down the pipes in terms of future products, precision search product predicated on the 6Sense technology the momentum and the conversation is moving less to price and more to the benefits that the technology brings to the table. So that's working well for us. And based on what we're seeing now, that's most likely going to continue. With regard to -- if I quote the rest of the question correctly, with regard to posting, and call it, more traditional product, we're not seeing any significant change. Obviously, an individual customer, the price may go up or go down based on volume of what they're purchasing, et cetera. Whereas an overall matter across the board, things are pretty much even, prices are relatively stable. And maybe in a few cases, I think we're starting to see some improvement.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And are you assuming for next year that pricing will stay basically stable or maybe increase a little bit? Or how do you think about that?
componenttext: And are you assuming for next year that pricing will stay basically stable or maybe increase a little bit? Or how do you think about that?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Based on what we're seeing right now, we think things will remain fairly stable. Obviously, we can't speak to -- as we introduce new products, what that pricing may be and how that will fit in. But obviously, it's just a different market, and we'll see ho
componenttext: Based on what we're seeing right now, we think things will remain fairly stable. Obviously, we can't speak to -- as we introduce new products, what that pricing may be and how that will fit in. But obviously, it's just a different market, and we'll see how that goes. But for the current products, current suite of products, for the most part, I would say, things will stay relatively stable. We're not building anything into that 20% to 25% increase for price increases or anything of that sort.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: As Sal mentioned, in Q1, we're going to merge the two sides together. So basically, the traffic that's currently going towards the HotJobs site will go over to the Monster's site and the seekers from the trough as you see on the Yahoo!'s homepage will go
componenttext: As Sal mentioned, in Q1, we're going to merge the two sides together. So basically, the traffic that's currently going towards the HotJobs site will go over to the Monster's site and the seekers from the trough as you see on the Yahoo!'s homepage will go directly into the Monster site. The same thing for the employers, we are merging those sites together and merging the customers base together, as well as the seekers together. So starting some time in Q1, the experience will be a Monster experience, along with some of the other changes we are currently making.

componenttext: Darko, you type in HotJobs and then it'll take you to Monster?

componenttext: Correct. So if you go into a trough, there's going to be a Monster there. If you click on where it's currently HotJobs, there's going to be a Monster there. And if you type HotJobs, it will redirect you directly to the Monster. So for any [indiscernible] purposes or any main search engine, if you go there, it's going to automatically direct you to Monster.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lise, do you want to sum it a little bit on that in terms of the training and the bringing together -- how you're helping in bringing the two forces together.
componenttext: Lise, do you want to sum it a little bit on that in terms of the training and the bringing together -- how you're helping in bringing the two forces together.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We started out when we first brought the teams together doing some significant training. Every member of the HotJobs teams went through at least one day of training. Although they're still focusing on their products. And as we bring the two teams to
componenttext: Sure. We started out when we first brought the teams together doing some significant training. Every member of the HotJobs teams went through at least one day of training. Although they're still focusing on their products. And as we bring the two teams together, we will put them through close to two solid weeks of training so that they become fully integrated. We're pretty excited about it. We consider this kind of a privilege to have such as a great talent pipeline for our sales force. So we're focused on that. We're focused on on-boarding them with lots of training. And both teams are pretty excited.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not at this time. Maybe we'll get closer to that when we talk about -- when we give more specific guidance -- when we give you the earnings, I should say, for Q4. But right now, I don't think we're prepared for that. And to be honest with you, given our m
componenttext: Not at this time. Maybe we'll get closer to that when we talk about -- when we give more specific guidance -- when we give you the earnings, I should say, for Q4. But right now, I don't think we're prepared for that. And to be honest with you, given our mix and the changes in economies and political issues, et cetera, in different countries around the world that we operate in, we do operate in 56 different countries, a number of them significant. It really would be very difficult to do that. But overall, as I said, the numbers are 20% to 25% of growth across the board.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know you guys mentioned you're not going to break out HotJobs going forward. But I think in the past, you talked about maybe around 80-or-so-million of revenue and $20 million to $40 million in EBITDA. And I'm wondering if that still holds. And if you c
componenttext: I know you guys mentioned you're not going to break out HotJobs going forward. But I think in the past, you talked about maybe around 80-or-so-million of revenue and $20 million to $40 million in EBITDA. And I'm wondering if that still holds. And if you could maybe help us out in terms of breaking out next year. Is that 20% to 25% inclusive of HotJobs? What if it would be exclusive?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The 20% to 25% is inclusive of HotJobs, and everything we see about the business and about the acquisition gives us no reason to change the numbers we've talked about historically.
componenttext: The 20% to 25% is inclusive of HotJobs, and everything we see about the business and about the acquisition gives us no reason to change the numbers we've talked about historically.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to give you a little color. When you think about the 20% to 25%, we think of it as approximately 20% of it is Monster. On the high side, 5% would be HotJobs. Those numbers will stay. We just can't account for it in terms of showing how much is the co
componenttext: Just to give you a little color. When you think about the 20% to 25%, we think of it as approximately 20% of it is Monster. On the high side, 5% would be HotJobs. Those numbers will stay. We just can't account for it in terms of showing how much is the contribution from one versus the other as time goes on. As the sales forces are converging and salespeople of HotJobs and salespeople of Monster are working together to present a solution, an overall solution to a customer, it gets very difficult to say how much is the HotJobs versus how much will be Monster. I can tell you that this is already occurring. As one example I have in mind right now, there was a large staffing company transaction where there was business that had been done with that customer, both from HotJobs as well as from the Monster side. Thankfully, the overall transaction when you added the historical HotJobs and historical Monster, the new transaction was a bit higher in total. But exactly what you could attribute to HotJobs and what you could attribute to Monster, really gets very vague. And even if we would give you numbers, it really would be meaningless.

componenttextpreview: Sure. We definitely see it as a source of traffic for us and as a tool for the seekers. We launched an iPhone app very recently. iPad is next. Android is following that fairly quickly. Clearly, in addition to being a tool for seekers and the employers, we
componenttext: Sure. We definitely see it as a source of traffic for us and as a tool for the seekers. We launched an iPhone app very recently. iPad is next. Android is following that fairly quickly. Clearly, in addition to being a tool for seekers and the employers, we're also looking at the opportunities to monetize from the advertising standpoint, those channels. So we see it as a very important future channel, and we want to figure out how do we best monetize that tool. And we ask that the launch of that this moment has received a large number of people downloading them and we plan to, almost every quarter, launch a new app for one of these platforms.

componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Tim McHugh with William Blair.

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask two questions here if I could. First on the Internet advertising segment, there's been a lot of commentary out of some of the education companies, which I believe is a decent-sized customer for IAF. Can you talk about how big that is? A
componenttext: Just wanted to ask two questions here if I could. First on the Internet advertising segment, there's been a lot of commentary out of some of the education companies, which I believe is a decent-sized customer for IAF. Can you talk about how big that is? And then, those companies have talked about kind of cutting back on some of the lead spending that they'll be doing. So have you seen that or is that a source of risk as you look forward? And then secondly, Sal, maybe qualitatively, can you talk a little bit about, you gave one example of the conversations you're having with clients as you try and shift them from HotJobs to kind of the combined basis. But what's been kind of the retention of that client base and the ability to bring the pricing up relative to HotJobs old pricing? Just maybe qualitatively how that's meeting your expectations post the deal?

headline: Monster Worldwide, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, with regard to the first part of your question, the decline or the concerns regarding the education activity is not a phenomenon of Q3. Its been building throughout the year and really accelerated I guess in Q2 and its continued int
componenttext: I think, first of all, with regard to the first part of your question, the decline or the concerns regarding the education activity is not a phenomenon of Q3. Its been building throughout the year and really accelerated I guess in Q2 and its continued into Q3. So we've been preparing and looking for, as business changes, as the methodology changes, as the concerns change for us to change with it and be ready to move into different forms, different client base, et cetera, in addition to our traditional ones to broaden ourselves and diversify in the education space. Overall, our education revenue has stayed relatively flat to slightly improved, and I mean very slightly, which given the turmoil that's been in the industry, particularly on the for profits side, we feel very good about that. Now I understand that this coming Monday or Tuesday, the government is going to release more guidance on what's involved, what they want in terms of governance on lead generation and quality of candidate in essence. We're obviously very keen to see that and understand it. But we are really prepared and this is something we've been tackling and dealing with for the past six months, I would say, roughly. And I think are in a fairly good position. We'll see what the doctor in tests say and then we'll continue to maneuver around it. With regard to pricing in HotJobs et cetera, right now the discussion has been centered much more on the solution, the quality of the product mix and a full-blown solution and we haven't seen any -- most important, we haven't seen any significant departures of customers et cetera. And what we have seen,  and in terms of pricing, we see the Monster pricing basically continuing as I said before stabilizing and staying stable. And for the most part, the HotJobs pricing either we're improving where we're be able to introduce a high-quality product, a model product, a different product or staying the same. So we don't see -- we're certainly not seeing a deterioration on the Monster side or the HotJobs side. In tandem, they seem to be moving along sort of evenly, if you will. I caution, and this has always been -- it's a risk in the transaction. We thought it's a risk, in all of Tim's numbers et cetera that we allowed for, and I think fairly conservatively when we enter the transaction, that there could be some breakage. But we haven't seen that yet, but it's early. It's only been two months or so now since the closing of the transaction. And so in the next months, next few quarters, will ultimately tell the tale. But as of right now, we don't have any serious concerns. We're watching it carefully. It's something we've been on guard for since conceptualizing the transactions, to be honest with you. But it's not something that surprises or hurt us to this point in time.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Tiffany, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Monster Worldwide Quarter Three 2010 Earnings Call.
